solid production values but not a whole lot of anything else.For such a horror obsessed director, its curious that Wheatley wasn't able to instill his own brand of devilishly inventive scares or chills into Du Maurier's oft-imitated tale as Rebecca for the most part remains thrill free throughout with the scariest thing throughout some odd sleepwalking and some creepy stares.Without these chills and thrills Hammer and James have a lot of work to do as the seemingly mismatched couple and the two charismatic performers aren't able to elevate proceedings a whole lot with the initial wins they have as head over heels lovers quickly giving way to a hum-drum series of procedurals that wont surprise or entertain anyone that's ever seen or read a tale of this ilk before and at days end, we come to an overarching sense that we just don't care enough about these two characters as Rebecca draws slowly towards its end game.Final Say -A pretty to look at but otherwise lifeless redo of the Rebecca tale, Ben Wheatley once more fails to capture the magic of his early career work in what is another disappointment in his growing collection of mid to low-tier of films.2 Oyster breakfasts out of 5

reviews.review_title: Lily James as Mrs.De Winters is laughable
reviews.content: Horrible sums it up in one word. Lily James cringey body language makes you uncomfortable.

I have never seen such a beautiful film miss the mark so completely! Even though the visual aspect of the film was beautiful, nothing else In this film was believable! The acting was terrible, the characters completely ludicrous, the writing excruciatingly bad & the overall delivery of the film failed on all levels! I've never written a review like this before. But then, I've never seen a movie like this before! The trailer had me intrigued & was done well, and the beginning of the film seemed promising! But as I got into the film, it just became weird. I have no idea what happened to this film. It just kept getting worse! It was like watching a train wreck!

reviews.review_title: The mystery worked for Du Maurier and Hitchcock. Not here.
reviews.content: The clash between the heroine and the memory of Rebecca was rich with romantic triumph and despair in the novel, but Wheatley settles for the weakest form of romance: niceness.

I understand why many may not like this, the book is ALWAYS better than the movie. However, having never even heard of the book I enjoyed the movie very much. Yes it was slow paced but perfect for a quiet rainy day with nothing else to do but curl up on the couch with a blanket and a cup of tea. Watch it for what it's worth and without reading the book first.

Fimul follows the book but unfortunately it doesn't shine ...
They failed to give the film freshness, energy, enough color. Even if it has the air of mystery, it does not have the necessary force to captivate you, to make you startle, to excite you.

What a travesty of a film. The era of the thirties/forties, isn't captured at all. The timidity of the narrator is missed completely. And the moodiness of Mr. DeWinter with his great burden of guilt is absent. Oddly wooden performances drag the whole mess downwards.The 1940 Hitchcockian/Du Maurier masterpiece should have been left alone.. Laurence Olivier as Maxim, Joan Fontaine as Mrs. De Winter and Judith Anderson as Mrs. Danvers we perfect casting and had multiple award and nominations.This cast don't even come close but trudge through the leaden dialogue. And the script is wincingly awful. Dreams/nightmares in any script to me are like unimaginative filler.All points are for the great old house and the staff and the furnishings. And the cars.And oh yeah, they murdered the ending. And not in a good way. Daphne and Alfred, so sorry.

reviews.review_title: A terrible mongrel halfway between "Crimson Peak" and "The Great Gatsby"
reviews.content: I have to acknowledge that I absolutely love both the novel by Daphne du Maurier on which this movie is based and the original film adaptation by Alfred Hitchcock. So I already had misgivings upon finding out that a remake was going to be made... and starring no other than Lily James and Armie Hammer! To me, that was no incentive to watch the new version. That being said, I decided to give it an opportunity. But to no avail.First of all, like I just said, I find that Armie Hammer and Lily James are completely miscast as Mr. and Mrs. de Winter. I don't really like Lily James as I find most of her performances (e.g. in "War and Peace", "The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society" or "Cinderella") rather insipid. Still, I think that she can do a good job if given some specific kind of characters, like Lady Rose in "Downton Abbey". As for Armie Hammer, he is not one of my favorite actors either, but the problem for me remains the same: he just does not fit into this role! His looks, age and acting style just make him unsuitable. Of course, it would be really difficult to find two actors who would equal Joan Fontaine's and Laurence Olivier's performances, but I think the casting team was simply looking for two popular young actors. Hence the miscasting and the lack of chemistry between them. However, I must concede that Kristin Scott Thomas was a good choice for Mrs. Danvers. I wouldn't have thought of Sam Riley as Jack Favell, but he is not bad either.However, the cast is only one of the many issues with this film. Almost everything, from photography and special effects to music or costumes (Mrs. de Winter wearing trousers? Come on!), seemed so absurd and out of place to me - to say nothing about the film pace (at some points, especially at the beginning, I felt like I was watching a trailer rather than an actual movie) and simply the way the story is told, its tone and aesthetic. Starting with the scenes at Montecarlo where Mrs. Van Hopper hysterically makes fun of the protagonist because of the way she behaves with Maxim and that sex scene at the beach (really... WTF? It felt like a perfume commercial), followed by Maxim's sleepwalking, the Manderley ball, that melodramatic murder trial and everything else... Many important details of the story were poorly explained, and I could not help but laugh at the way some of the original movie's capital scenes (Mrs. Danvers encouraging Mrs. de Winter to commit suicide, Mrs. de Winter showing her frock for the ball...) were copied.To conclude: I am a millennial who loves both classic and contemporary cinema. I am not particularly conservative in my taste and I always feel curious about remakes. And still, this is not worth watching. 2/10.

The 2020 version of Rebecca isn't the worst remake we have seen. It fact it was pleasantly good in its own.. Ofcourse it would be unfair to compair it with the Oscar winning Hitchcock classic but this adaption is decent in its way ! Lily James looks stunning throughout and delivers a decent performance. The lady as Mrs. Denver's delivers a brilliant performance ! The film though lacks the eerie atmosphere of the original one and the uneven editing at times with scenes moving from one doesn't do good either ! However the emotive part involving the two leads is pretty good. The ending feels a bit rushed and no way could match the original . Having said that first time Rebecca watchers will love it and those who are fan of the Hitchcock classic like me won't mind it either... It's a decent watch. !

reviews.review_title: Grimly atmospheric and dutifully Gothic, but...
reviews.content: While his films might be an acquired taste, it cannot be denied that Ben Wheatley is one of the most unconventional voices in contemporary cinema. Personally, I love Ben Wheatley and have enjoyed all of his films to varying degrees (with High-Rise, Wheatley's most polarizing feature in a filmography full of them, being my favorite of his), one reason being that I find his unorthodox approach to filmmaking, in an era where it almost feels like idiosyncrasy in filmmaking is sadly dying, to be highly refreshing. However, given that multiple adaptations of Daphne du Maurier's Rebecca already exist, with the most famous one being the Best Picture winner directed by Alfred Hitchcock, I couldn't help but be highly curious as to what Wheatley would do with this project, and was even cautious after discovering that this is the first of Ben Wheatley's features to not be written by him or his writing partner Amy Jump. It certainly didn't help that the the trailer left much to be desired.That said, maybe I shouldn't have been worried, because even despite operating on a more accessible level, this new adaptation of Daphne du Maurier's acclaimed novel not only proves to be another stellar effort from an idiosyncratic filmmaker with an already commendable body of work, but is one that even improves on Hitchcock's film in various aspects.

'Rebecca' is one of Alfred Hitchcock's most admired films, so it takes guts to remake it in 2020. Anyone following in Hitch's footsteps is sure to be vilified for it. But let's be honest: this is not really a remake of a Hitchcock movie, but a new film version of a novel that has been adapted for the big and small screen several times.I think this version is a very decent one. For one thing, it looks gorgeous. The locations, the clothes, the cars: it's a feast for the eyes. Lead actress Lily James looks the whole time as if she is modeling for a '30's fashion magazine, which is nice. Apart from the looks of the film, the screenplay is also good. Then again, with Du Maurier's material it's hard to go wrong. 'Rebecca' is a story containing everyting it takes for a good film: suspense, character development, an improbable romance, sinister atmosphere and a spectacular ending. The fact that the deceased title character of the film hangs as a shadow over everything that happens, is what made Hitchcock's film such a good movie. But the same goes for the 2020 version.Director Ben Wheatly had to follow in Hitchcock's footsteps, but the lead actors have Lawrence Olivier and Joan Fontaine as examples - both with formidable reputations. I think both did quite well. The emphasis in this film is less on Maxim de Winter. So Armie Hammer's part is secondary to that of Lily James as Mrs. de Winter, the simple girl marrying a rich aristocrat. She succeeds quite well in combining innocent vulnerability and female attractiveness. But the show is stolen by Kristin Scott Thomas as the creepy Mrs. Danvers, the housekeeper of the De Winter estate, who radiates hostility while staying polite.After I watched this movie, I put the dvd of Hitchcock's 1940 version in the player. It had quite some nice Hitchcockian moments, but at the same time the melodrama is dated, the acting is stiff and the black & white doesn't do justice to the splendour of De Winter's estate. So in my opinion, the new 'Rebecca' is an enjoyable update.

I finished in 2 days because it is quite long and very slow movie. Cinematography was very nice, location, scenes, the house were perfect, I liked acting too but what was missing exacty , I have no idea. For example last 20 min, you can understand what happened to Rebecca but you don't feel anything good or bad, you watch just for finish the movie. Something is really missing. If I find Hitchcock version of this, I will watch immediately.

reviews.review_title: Not as terrible as all these reviews say
reviews.content: So Rebecca follows the whirlwind romance and and subsequent complications of Mr. Maxim De Winter (Armie Hammer - I know 😬😖) and his new wife (Lily James). This film is an adaptation of the novel of the same name, and follows the new Mrs. De Winter as she attempts to fill the shoes of the mysterious, alluring, and tragically deceased late Mrs. Rebecca De Winter.This film is a beautiful period piece with fabulous cinematography, and very textured settings. It's kind of a slow burn, and definitely takes you on a ride. However, I felt that the pacing was very stunted, and alternated wildly between sprinting and walking painfully slow. The mystery of the story is doled out carefully, and the tidbits the film gives you make you work for them in patience for sure.Although this film has been generally panned online, I actually kind of enjoyed it. May have been because I set the bar pretty low, but it was still an enjoyable experience.A word of warning - don't let the trailer fool you. This is not a psychological thriller mystery - although it certainly has its moments. It's more a frantic and super tragic love story, where you just feel bad for Lily James because *nobody is nice to her at all* which is super tragic.All in all, 7/10 - would recommend if you're interested, but wouldn't try to make you watch it if you didn't want to.

Rebecca is a new version of a famous novel and perhaps even more famous Hitchcock film which is simply said far above this version but still this wasnt completly awful watch and it had some solid staff in it.Lily and Armie were good together and they had solid chemistry but simply said their acting abbilities are not even close to a level of Joan Fontaine and Laurance Olivier but they still give they best job concering their material.Story was somewhat fine but it had many referances to a book and 40 version in which some scenes looked to similiar.Rebecca was in end not surprisingly not better then older version but it had a cute stars

Rebecca is one of my all-time favourite movies, but not this version. Alfred Hitchcock's 1940 film is a masterpiece, and the remake does not hold a candle to it. The characters here are impersonal, the plot changes nonsensical, and overall, the movie falls flat. Extremely disappointing!

reviews.review_title: I'll probably forget about this in a couple days
reviews.content: Pros:I enjoyed the thrill aspects of the film - especially the 2nd half of the filmI thought Armie Hammer and Lily James gave condemnable roles each - special shoutout to Keeley Hawes who I thought stole the show every time she was on screen.I appreciated the plot and its original source materialCons:I felt the first half of the film was slightly forgettableI did feel the film could've maybe gone slightly more into the heart of the source materialOverall, I thought 'Rebecca' was a good watch and certainly something to fill the time. While I wasn't blown away by the film, I thought there were aspects that made it shine. Performances were good and the plot twists towards the final act were enjoyable. Although, I can't help but feel this film will not stay with me for very long. There is an original film from 1940 I have yet to see, which I will check out and compare. But this version of 'Rebecca' was just ok for me.Quote - "I don't believe in ghosts" - Mrs. de WinterRating - 2.5/5

I love the story of 'Rebecca' and the 1940 film is one of my favorite films. Hitchcock did that story remarkably well. I actually preferred Hitchcock's version to the novel; don't get me wrong, I loved the novel but in the confines of what Hitchcock had to work in he did a marvelous job at making one immersed in the story.The production value in this is well done. I even think the actors were the right choice for the roles but it seemed too modern even in its setting. The haunting aspect didn't come soon enough. I think it would have worked better if they started at the house in retrospect of the narration; though in the novel it was more of a remembrance after Manderlay burned down and they were living abroad.Gothic style doesn't necessarily mean dark and gloomy; everything in this is bright and shiney, for the most part, and that didn't bother me. 'Rebecca' to me was always a love story first and a psychological thriller second. The love story being between the new Mrs. De Winter and Max rather than Rebecca and Max because Max never loved Rebecca and Rebecca only loved herself, if even that. Mrs. Danvers loved Rebecca because they were basically the same person: cruel-hearted.Overall, it's a nice effort but doesn't stand up to the novel nor Hitchcock's version. What I think people could have gotten into is a prequel to 'Rebecca'. Or at least, I could.

I love the original classic with Laurence Olivier and Joan Fontaine in the lead roles. The acting in this version is so very bland by comparison. By half-way through, I realized I really didn't care about any of the characters in this version.While I get they might want to update the script a bit, it really just doesn't strike anywhere near the tension, mystery, romance of the original. And the wardrobe? Don't get me started on that, or the bleached blond hair. ;)None of the characters in this version are nearly as interesting or alluring. I expected more out of Kristen Scott Thomas, but even her Mrs. Danvers fell flat.Not a very good version of a great story.

The only thing about this makeover of Daphne Du Maurier's classic novel that resembles said classic novel are the character names and locations and THAT'S IT.It is a dreadful, sloppy, badly written, badly acted, ripped up, torn down and shabbily patched up, cheap reimagining of the original novel. It's an insult.

This is NOT a psychological thriller. It's a boring romantic drama. I would give it 3/10 because the cinematography, acting and period props/dresses were good. And perhaps I would have given this a better score if it wasn't said to be a psychological thriller. Although I wouldn't have wasted 2 hours of my life I'd it hadn't been advertised as such.If you like long, drawn out period drama pieces you'll love this movie.

I adore the novel, and I enjoyed the Hitchcock adaptation, but have always loved Wheatley's films (my absolute favourite is 'A Field in England' - just astoundingly clever and mad). So, while this version of 'Rebecca' isn't as psychologically extreme as 'High-Rise' or 'A Field in England', it's not far off. But that's what Wheatley does, so very well - he anchors everything in realism, and when that foundational starting point is teamed with du Maurier's source material, the result is thrilling, compelling, and gorgeously ambiguous. Your allegiances will change, as they do in Wheatley's other films, and as they might in real life. Character who may have remained literary or filmic tropes and stereotypes will flesh out in this version, into empathetic, understandable humans. I wish I could say more, but I won't - just watch it!Wheatley's take is original - he guides the source material into a non-hysterical, far-from-clichéd adaptation. Wonderful shades of Austen's 'Northanger Abbey', ala Catherine Morland and Henry Tilney, realising what is real and what is imagined, and how to act. My only criticism is that the last movement was too fast for me - a whirlwind of loose ends tidied up - but then again, the focus had to dwell on Mrs de Winter's experiences and related character growth (sorry about being abstract - am dodging spoilers here!).I'm looking forward to repeat viewings of this version, if not always for the puzzle unfolding before me, then for the ingenious shot choices and cinematography, let alone perfect casting.

Each version of Rebecca has it's pros and cons. The Hitchcock version with Lawrence Olivier and Joan Fontaine is just too dated by today's standards. I used to think the 1979 version with Jeremy Brett and Anna Massey was fine. The acting was good and the story effectively told. But nobody was very attractive in that version so it was interesting to see an updated 2020 version with such A list actors as the lead characters. Lily James is such an animated actress she makes anything seem involving. That's why the first part of the show is watchable and her romance is nice to watch. There is more passion than they could have shown in the earlier versions. The tinted view of the South of France is beguiling. But during the court case and the ending there is a lack of intensity and the story feels dated and rushed. The reveal from Maxim about Rebecca's death is weak and unclear. Armie Hammer looks right for these classic older stories. Maybe it's the 30s costume but he looks more than usual like a giant. He isn't quite tortured enough and maybe because he doesn't have a British accent or even put one on he seems less effective during the intense moments.
The settings are nice from the South of France to the coast line in England to the interiors of the country house. The house didn't feel creepy like in the 79 version. But the director used too much dark lighting maybe unaware at that time that everything would be on TV these days instead of the cinema. Kristin Scott Thomas isn't menacing enough as Mrs Danvers - maybe because she is still beautiful even though she is older.
Despite the flaws fans of the story will want to check out this 2020 version.
I find the story engaging because it poses many questions which makes me keep watching to find the answers.

I thoroughly enjoyed this rendition of Rebecca. The actors played their roles well? Daphne DuMaurier novel of Rebecca is a good one so of course the story and plot were wonderful. What was nice about this version you see more of the initial courtship of the main characters.

reviews.review_title: A strong take on the themes of the book, but not without some issues
reviews.content: I see that it averages 6 stars at the moment, which is unjust. I suspect without seeing the reviews that a lot of people will be comparing to the last movie (naturally) and Hitchcock has a fanatical following. And Hitchcock's movie is a brilliant, iconic movie. One of the best movies of all time.But it was also very Hitchcock movie - his voice came through strong, the noir thriller very present.With this remake I felt Daphne De Maurier's voice was heard more strongly than before.Where it really excels is that claustrophobic feeling of Rebecca. A young nameless woman subsumed by Rebecca at every turn. Mrs Danvers is more nuanced too, less outright-crazy and more obsessive in this turn. Kristin Scott Thomas is a delight.There are some issues that detract. The age gap between the lead actors is a real problem. For me part of the narrative is that it's a much older man taking a young, naïve woman as his wife. Here the ages are very close, and as such its loses a big dynamic.The revelation and about turn of the main character is a bit too quick. And indeed Lily James was good but not quite as vulnerable as I feel she should be. Indeed she felt quite modern with a fire underneath, and I'm not sure it quite works in terms of the journey. I could do without a couple of lazy plot devices such as dreams and flashbacks to tell the story.But all in all this is a very good adaptation. It doesn't tell a hugely different story to Hitchcock's, but it is different if you look closely and listen to the themes. It's well directed and effective, and Daphne De Maurier shines through and for that alone I applaud it. Judge the movie on its own merits.

reviews.review_title: Why remake a film when you have nothing of interest to add?
reviews.content:
Right, so, since we so admire Daphne du Maurier's Rebecca we're going to make a new adaptation, only:We don't like the extremely shy personality of the protagonist, it's just not very 2020, so while she still remains somewhat insecure, we're basically making her a completely different person, who takes charge of situations, has no qualms about having pre-marital sex with Maxim, firing Mrs. Danvers (twice!), and breaking into doctors' offices in the middle of the night.We don't like the age difference of at least 20 years between the protagonist and Maxim de Winter, so scratch that.We think the story lacks excitement and action, because we either don't appreciate the subtle build-up of tension in the book, or we don't trust our audience to. Therefore we're adding extra intrige, an arrest, a bribe, and a criminal investigation that wasn't there before.Building on the previous point, come to think of it, we don't even like the thirties and the British mentality of that time, so let's only alude to that, in an almost comical way, and meanwhile have everyone practice only the bare minimum of stiff upper lip, while also giving away bits of information that aren't supposed to be shared with the audience until much later in the story.Lastly, we either don't think there's enough drama in the story or, again, don't trust our audience to pick up on it, so we'll throw in a last emotional scene with the protagonist and Mrs. Danvers, who subsequently throws herself off a cliff.Now, halfway through watching I figured I was probably unfairly biased, because I'm a big fan of the book and have already seen two film adaptations of it, my favourite being the 1997 one with Charles Dance and Emilia Fox in the lead, so I thought: maybe I should keep an open mind and just view this as a completely new interpretation of the book.
However, the crux, the axis, the pointe of Rebecca, no matter how else you may interpret it, is the lack of communication and making of assumptions between Maxim and his second wife that causes the wildest misconceptions on both sides and gets dramatically revealed near the end. The protagonist's very shy and insecure personality, the age difference between her and Maxim, and the obsessive adherence to decorum of the time actually go a very long way in explaining how this can happen in the first place. Leaving all these factors out, or at least diminishing them severely, and also giving away too much along the way (like the early mention of Rebecca's note) chipped away at the mystery and the suspense and therefore took away a lot from the eventual reveal. The reveal which, by the way, seemed to kind of "got over with" as quickly as possible, so the train of events could get picked up again.In conclusion: it's as if the original story first got wattered down in essentials and then enhanced again by the addition of a lot of unnecessary drama. I don't see what this film was supposed to be adding.I still award two stars because there was one alteration I rather liked: the fact that Mrs. van Hopper was on to what the protagonist was up to. When you think about it, that actually makes a lot of sense, because in a hotel like that there would be a lot of gossip and the comings and goings of Maxim de Winter would definitely not go unnoticed, as, for some reason, they did in the novel.
Also: I liked Keeley Hawes as Maxim's sister.
Great acting, but unbalanced story. In the beginning the main actors have a totally different role compared to the end.

reviews.review_title: Unsuccessful modern take on renowned tale
reviews.content: STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday MorningA young woman (Lily James) becomes a 'social assistant' to a snobby older posh lady, only to catch the eye of Maxim de Winter (Arnie Hammer), a renowned figure on the social scene. Before long, she has become Mrs. de Winter, and moved in to Manderlay, Maxim's stately home, although her new husband is strangely guarded on certain things. All of a sudden, strange occurances begin taking place, which seem to be initiated by Mrs. Danvers (Kristen Scott Thomas), the resident housekeeper, all threatening to reveal a secret too terrifying for words.For such an avid film watcher, I must confess to being far less cultured than I would like to admit, and so with a touch of embarrassment, I must say this is the first incarnation of Daphne Du Maurier's well regarded novel Rebecca that I have seen. My first experience of hearing 'last night, I dreamt again of Manderlay', and 'the second Mrs. de Winter' and of Mrs. Danvers, alas with a modern spin by director Ben Wheatley, adding his distinctive touch. But sadly, even he can't bring this old tale into present times.There's always some potential in bringing an enduring tale in to present times, but the old Hollywood style and period dialogue just comes off as alienating to a present day film viewer, not acquainted with the story or the timeframe it exists in. As a result, it just lingers on for the most part, failing to really engage or draw you into the story, only really coming to life in the final half. It captures the fashions and style of the time quite well, and does generate some intrigue, but not really enough to last all the way.It might have helped if I had as much affection for the tale as Wheatley obviously has, and maybe if I saw some different versions of it, I might think of it differently, but this modern update of it simply leaves me cold. **
In all fairness, if Armie Hammer was my husband, I would also help to cover up his character's act of murder too.UPDATE: I'd probably need to.

reviews.review_title: A tour of Europe during the pandemic
reviews.content: This movie reminds me of "Midnight in Paris" where popular European tourist spots are showcased beautifully, making you picture yourself visiting those places as they pop up on the screen. "Rebecca" is the pandemic version: Just look, but don't touch. We want to visit those places, but we can't right now, so this movie is good enough. Unfortunately, that's about all it's good for - the scenery and a couple of acting performances. It's interesting to see Aunt Lydia from "The Handmaid's Tale" fame as a spoiled socialite. Then we have Armie Hammer. There is really nothing special about his acting performance; it's just he is quite a sight to behold. Criminally handsome and tall, his future leading man role opportunities are endless.
Kept me guessing what was going on, which I always like in a movie. Didn't know who to trust and who to like but then came together really well in the end. A good watch- would recommend.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film from start to finish, it had me completely engaged. You never know what's going to happen next and all actors were cast perfectly!
Shocked about negative reviews my advice watch this film, you will enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: Unfair to compare but it doesn't live up to the name.
reviews.content:
It is hard to remake a masterpiece. Laurence Olivier as Maxim, Joan Fontaine as Mrs. De Winter and Judith Anderson as Mrs. Danvers with Alfred Hitchcock directing - delivered a triumph of two Oscars and nine nominations. This should have signaled to everyone concerned that any rendition will fall short. Unfortunately Netflix gambled wrong on this one, however, Lily James is a joy to watch as Mrs. De Winter and manages to make the otherwise lackluster movie interesting. Director Ben Wheatley brings us a cleaner more rational version of the novel, while Armie Hammer misses on the depth that the 1940 version cast in his place, Laurence Olivier. To compare Hammer to one of the best actors of all time is quite unfair, however Hammer's performance doesn't give the character of Maxim a chance to breathe in the nuances needed.
The same goes for Kristin Scott Thomas' performance of Mrs. Danvers, although its hard to live up to one of the most iconic performances (by Judith Anderson) in cinematic history.

reviews.review_title: It's not fair to compare it to the first one
reviews.content:
This movie it's beautifully made and acted, so stop with the hate.
The acting of Kristin Scott Thomas is flawless, Armie Hammer is the perfect Maxim and Lily is splendid portraying such a vulnerable, unprepared, naive girl!
Loved it! Well done!

What is the reason for making a new adaptation of a literary work? That is the question every filmmaker must ask himself before facing this task. Apparently, the director and scriptwriter of this new version of "Rebecca" never asked themselves; or if they did, they found answers to that question they could not transcribe in images and on the film itself.
If it was just showing scenes in the south of France on screen: welcome; serves as a tourist reference. But by trying to approach the book with "more fidelity" than Hitchcock did, they managed to get even further away from the Daphne du Maurier story.
"Rebecca" is a gothic novel, something that the makers of this version seem to be unaware of; or maybe they don't know the meaning of "gothic" or how it is translated into a movie.
The answer is simple: see the 1940 film by Hitchcock, which, even affected by the implacability of the Hay's code, not only manages to reflect the essence of the novela, but also transcends as a classic, a masterpiece of cinema.
This mess is just that: a mess. A subset of mediocre performances coupled with poor production (it is not known why, because this film obviously had a much larger budget than Hitch had). And the two main characters are a disaster. Lily James (not a bad actress, let me clarify) all the time overacts her role as a shy and insecure creature, to the point that it becomes very annoying. Armie Hammer is pure vanilla, without a trace of guilt, problems and insecurities; a pretty face to wander around the screen from time to time and attract sighing damsels. Mrs Danvers is stripped of all the sexual ambiguity that the novel, and the 1940 film, subtly suggest. Honestly, the performance of Scott Thomas is the only reason anybody could claim for watching this film, and even her is limited excessively by the script.
The ending of the film is really so out of character and far from the novel that it is, in itself, tragic. The reality is that this film is neither a romantic comedy, nor a mystery film, much less Gothic at all, as it is the novel on which it is based. So, what is it? Well, you don't know: it wants to be everything (perhaps to appeal to a larger audience), but it is nothing. Rather, something is: a disaster.

reviews.review_title: it's not great but I enjoyed it
reviews.content: I like the change they made in the story. i read the book and i watched the original movie. in both of them the story was... like something missing. in this version everything fits very well.

I'm glad I rated this before I read other reviews. The book is one of my all time favorites, but I have always been unhappy with basically no conclusion. I am thrilled with this movie version. Scenery was beautiful. Perfect fit to the novel. Kristin Scott Thomas was spot on!

The story is so over the top it's ridiculous. Half an hour in I stopped taking this movie seriously at all. Lily James' acting was quite bad, also way too dramatic and over the top. Her body language and expressions are absolutely hilarious. 5 stars because other actors did well and the movie kept me somewhat engaged.

reviews.review_title: Decent drama thriller that could have been so much more but is left feeling empty.
reviews.content: 3 out of 5 stars.Rebecca is a fair drama thriller film that is beautiful to look at with the set locations, cinematography, and Ben Wheatly trying to deliver a mystery thriller direction. But it does feel short handed with surprises and twists. Which the film is short on surprises. Which many may not be surprised.The plot follows Lily James character as she runs into Maxim (Armie Hammer) who owns an estate. They both fall for each other. When Lily is being driven away. Maxim proposes to her. Which they get married and she moves into the estate. She soon finds out he is a widow after his former wife was lost at sea. And apparently drowned. When Mrs. Danvers (Kristen Scott Thomas) is rude and unwelcoming to her. She discovers that there is so much more that she does not know.It was a decent plot. Starting out as Lily James is a girl that wants to travel. And takes the companionship as a job to get her to travel. Until she runs into Armie Hammers character which the films direction becomes like a romantic drama film. Except Hammers character has an attitude every time she brings up about his former wife who passed away. Or avoids talking about his past. The plot does change gears in the final half hour when the twist is revealed. And it becomes something more of a serious drama. Which is also where it disappoints with a twist that feels a little short handed.Lily James is lovable as Mrs. de Winters. She is sweet and curious. It is difficult to not like her character. James delivers a great performance. Armie Hammer is good as Maxim. Playing a mysterious character which he is struggling with his past. Kristen Scott Thomas is okay playing Mrs. Danvers. Who looks disgusted every time she sees Mrs. de Winters.Ben Wheatly does deliver a beautiful cinematography and tone with the set locations. And trying to build an eerie bleak mystery. But it lacks momentum or thrills.

The story had so much opportunity, unfortunately it got completely wasted.A complete miscast of the lead roles and a complete miss of building ANY believable emotional connection between the characters, made this movie fee like riding on a dirt road with the main characters being a couple of stones that bang Mosley abasing each other in every other pothole.There is SO many things they could have done different, but certainly the best would have been to make this a mini series instead of a movie; give the character and story time to breath and sit in.

As a fan of the original movie , I found this to be a terrible remake ant I could not watch the entire thing . Had to watch half the next morning . Armie Hammer is not Olivier and James is no Joan Fontaine and the theme of the older man and the timid young woman was not part of this movie. Mrs Danvers wearing makeup ?? In addition the clothing was not the right attire for the period , except for the one skirt that was similar to the original . In the original version Manderly was a scary looking place but in this movie it was just a house I could go on and on, but this was so sad. I personally am returning to Manderly tonight , but the original version as I want to forget this one

reviews.review_title: Do not waste the 2 hours it takes to watch this Tripe
reviews.content: Each of these actors individually are wonderful in their own right. However this combination is in my opinion a heretical farce.I am before I begin a fan of the original 1940 Hitchcock movie and the Book itself. To be fair I was so open to this adaption.It broke my heart to see such clearly defined characters, portrayed completely without compassion or merit. Why would anyone do this?These characters would stretch any actors chops and are wonderfully meaty, to use acting terms.There was so much scope, however all they did was climb in the boat with Rebecca and drown!

REBECCA is many things. Gorgeous. Spooky. Romantic. Macabre. Melodramatic. It is about many things. Love. Insecurity. Death. Memory. Loyalty. Revenge. It is colorful and kinetic and alive and lush and haunting. Perfect? No. An Oscar-winning Best Picture? Probably not. But it works incredibly well on it's own terms. If you throw all preconceived notions out the window and you take it in as is, a kaleidoscope of emotions and sounds and haunting images, as well as the great performances by a trio of incredibly talented actors, you'll find something here that sticks in your brain as Rebecca de Winter does with our heroine.Technically not a masterpiece, but a 10/10 experience in my mind.

The lead actress was incredibly annoying!! She was so weird. The writing was horrendous, the lead was so weak and timid, she jumped at everything and was incredibly irritating. The only reason I gave it a 1 was because of the beautiful house and scenery.

reviews.review_title: Boring and unfaithful to the book's quality
reviews.content: The ending is a mess, the acting unconvincing and overall it's a big waste of time. Just read the novel, don't watch this boring "adaptation" which doesn't do justice to the mystery, suspense and subtlety of the original story.

reviews.review_title: Falls flat like an unkept promis
reviews.content: Arnie Hammer is amazing as the deeply hurt widower, falling for a new love played by Lily James. What starts as a promising mystery, soon turns into a drama unaided by Lily James' overacting. Even the legendary Kristin Scott Thomas can't help but overact her way through something that slowly devolves into a rushed detective-like ending, explaining why and how Hammer became the widower he is.

reviews.review_title: Good performances but a pale imitation of the Original
reviews.content:
My Review- " Rebecca "My Score 6.5 /10I really was looking forward to this new version of Rebecca mainly because of the excellent cast that includes Lily James as the young and naive ladies maid who becomes the new Mrs De Winter and mistress of Mandalay. This is the role that earned Joan Fontaine her first Academy Award nomination in 1941.
Armie Hammer is suitably dashing as the troubled Maxime De Winter Master of Mandalay the stately mansion where Rebecca ended her days. This role was one of Sir Laurence Olivier's finest Screen performances and also won him an Academy Award Best Actor nomination.
Kristin Scott Thomas is very good as the deranged housekeeper of Mandalay Mrs Danvers who's obsession with her dead mistress Rebecca borders on psychotic. This role in the 1940 film version was brilliantly portrayed by Australian actress Dame Judith Anderson ,who was also nominated for Best Supporting Actress.
The Original 1940 film version of Daphne Du Maurier's best selling novel Rebecca did win the Best Motion Picture Oscar of 1941 and there's a good reason why ,it's a brilliant adaptation filmed in monochrome that suits the Gothic atmosphere of the novel.
This 2020 film version has been described as Downton Abbey on a bad day and I can understand why it's beautifully filmed and uses great locations but it's far from brilliant. Like the horrible 2017 remake of Daphne Du Maurier's My Cousin Rachel this version of Rebecca seems to me to be padded with new plot twists and a little dumbed down . The cast is excellent but I feel like most remakes of Classic films especially if the original was directed by Alfred Hitchcock it's almost impossible to make them work but this one is at least a good attempt.
They tried it with Psycho in 1998 with Gus Van Sant directing and it was a momentous flop this version of Rebecca is much better than that horrible remake of Psycho .
English Director Ben Wheatley certainly is no competition to Hitchcock and on checking his previous work I could see no justification for using him to direct such a famous remake.
It's at times a quite entertaining movie ,especially if you've never seen the original but it really has nothing to justify the expense and frankly all this great talent is wasted.
I did appreciate the little homage to Alfred Hitchcock's 1963 film "The Birds" , it couldn't have been accidental and did add a sense of foreboding but pleas don't remake that film.
The set designs costumes and homes in this new adaptation are beautiful
The first house used is the Jacobean-era Hatfield House in Hertfordshire, which was built in 1611 for Robert Cecil, a former statesman in the court of Queen Elizabeth I. Cranborne Manor in Dorset, originally built in 1207 as a hunting lodge, before being remodelled in the 17th century, also for Robert Cecil.
Loseley House, situated in 1,400 acres of countryside near Guildford in Surrey Petworth House in West Sussex, a late 17th-century Grade I listed country house, rebuilt in 1688 by Charles Seymour, 6th Duke of Somerset Osterley House is Isleworth, built in the 1570s for banker Sir Thomas Gresham Mapperton House, a Jacobean manor in Devon Blegberry Farm in Devon.
Shooting for the film also took place at Hartland Quay, a rocky seaside area on the North Devon coastline.
Rebecca is well worth a look ,you'll enjoy the performances and the settings but I much prefer the original film. One performance I really didn't like in this movie is the casting of Ann Dowd who was so evil as Aunt Lydia Clements in The Handmaid's Tale as Mrs Van Hopper the wealthy bitchy socialite who employs our young heroine narrator as her personal assistant. It's only a brief but important role at the beginning of the film .
Ann Dowd plays the character as an alcohol soaked broad and unlike Florence Bates in the original just comes across as dead common and left me wondering how she could ever have been accepted in high society.

This movie and its plot looks very promising and I would say first half an hour is very well built and done. I also like very much movie's performance (awesome costumes, scenery, camera, actors, music). However, it all goes away with second part. So much character and plot building to be just thrown away. I didn't read the novel, but I was personally really disappointed. So many questions placed but not answered. If Max hated Rebekka so much, why to keep everything just to remember her? Why to still have Mrs.Danvers around? Why he is sleepwalking into their former bedroom? Whose body was the body Max indentified for the first time? What about that freak in the cottage? And I can continue all day long.... Maybe if they focused the story on its main plot instead of trying to make it more mysterious and more twisted, it could have been awesome.

This one really annoyed me, specifically Lily James. Her character started out as fairly likeable, if a little vapid. The character then quickly changed into an annoying nervous, timid, gutless Lady of the house that played second fiddle to the servants. Then in the last 20 minutes, she turned into a decisive, strong and leading woman.
I've not read the book, but I strongly doubt that's how the character would have been written.
Kristin Scott Thomas gave the best performance of all.
It keeps you on edge, keeps you wondering and also romantic i don't understand why people reacted so badly to this movie because it was really enjoyable.

It was at times beautiful to look at. But what a mess of a film. Badly directed and edited, it managed to be both hysterical and boring all at once. Watch Hitchcock's original film version of Rebecca. Other than Lily James and some lovely cinematography, there's very little to see here. A mostly bad and ridiculous film.

Loved every part of it, a lot of people gave this a bad rating but for someone who hasn't seen the first movie, this is one of the best movies i've seen in a while, Beautifully shot! Super Cinematic! And a AWESOME story!

Ben Wheatley is a good director, when his heart is fascinated with a project, if the passion is high enough you can almost guarantee that what comes out from the finished product is going to be a hit from the Killing Fields to High Rise, through Kill List to Free Fire. He's full of the good stuff. He's good at self awareness however his latest Rebecca, is less fiery more running on fumes. From the start it's a glamorous romance set in the 30s, there's the costumes the cars and even the picturesque views look like a postcard from the 30s. But instead of wishing you were here, you'll be wishing you were gone, because the remake denies any existence it was even made from the original source material, and although you've got the Hitchcockian aspects it doesn't quite have the flair but then there's no Lawrence Olivier here. From the performances you can tell the lead actors are trying and they do a good job, sadly it doesn't go beyond 1st Base. And sadly for Wheatley this is a missed opportunity. 2/5.

Rebecca is one of my favourite classic novels and to say it is poor is an understatement. The casting is very weak with Lily James totally miscast and floundering as Mrs Dr Winters. Kristin Scott Thomas gives a good performance as befitting to the role she is cast with. However the original Mrs Danvers appears to be much darker. There is no no gothic backdrop or feel to this adaptation in comparison to to the 1940 Alfred Hitchcock film, that creates that psychological suspense. Some classics such as Rebecca are best left with their original version.

I don't remember ever seeing Armie Hammer but have always thought Lily James was beautiful, sadly they both miss dreadfully in this remake. Better maybe not to have attempted it as who could compete with Lawrence Oliver and the fragility and pathos of Joan Fontaine? Although Kirsten Scott Thomas did the best job of the cast as Mrs. Danvers, even she could not compare to original. The ball scene was simply bizarre and so unnecessary. Too bad as I was looking forward to this.

Rebecca is one of my all time favourite novels, so I was really looking forward to this film. What a disappointment! The first wrong bit was Mrs de Winter driving Maxim's car in the south of France. Purleese! She was a mousy thing with no confidence & he was not the sort to let a semi stranger drive his car. It went downhill from there. No rhododendrons in the drive at Manderley? They were an integral part of the book. Kristen Scott Thomas was the only bright spot in this whole miserable adaptation and she was suitably scary as Mrs Danvers, the evil housekeeper. Even she could not save this film though.It is many year since I last saw the original Hitchcock version but it was streets ahead of this one. The whole point of this story is the psychological suspense and this film missed it entirely. 2020 was a dreadful year and this did nothing to alleviate the misery.

Don't waste your time! It's boring, the characters don't connect with each other the way they should have and the storyline is all over the place. Worst part is, it goes for 2 hours and that's 2 hours of my life I'll never get back.

Is nothing scared in the Netflix greed for more money? What's next? A remake of Gone with the Wind? The sad thing is that today's film watchers know so very little about film classics or film history. The one constant they seem to have in common is that they do not like movies which are not in color. So we get this pathetic remake. And like 90% of all remakes it makes one cringe when compared to the original. Skip this rape of a classic and watch the original 1940 masterpiece instead. No, it's not in color. But as you're transfixed by the story, the writing, the acting, and the direction, you might even forget that it's not in splashy technicolor and that the light and shadows in black and white actually add to the mood of the film.

This adaptation of Daphne DuMaurier's magnificent novel cannot hold a candle to Alfred Hitchcock's 1938 adaptation starring Laurence Olivier and Joan Fontaine, nor is it comparable to the terrific 1997 BBC mini-series starring Charles Dance and Emilia Fox.As was his wont, Hitchcock added his own touch to his version of the book, similar to what he did in his other adaptations. For example, in both Rebecca and Suspicion, he changed the ending of the story or altered the presentation due to such considerations as audiences unwilling to accept stars like Laurence Olivier and Cary Grant being guilty of murder. The 1997 BBC adaptation was much truer to the original novel and was brilliantly presented.With respect to this 2020 Netflix entry, they should have left it in the can. Armie Hammer is unconvincing as a British aristocrat; he is neither Olivier nor Dance. Lily James suffers from poor direction and she hasn't anywhere near the acting chops of Joan Fontaine or Emilia Fox. Kristin Scott Thomas is a worthy successor to Dame Judith Anderson, offering an excellent portrayal of the wicked Mrs. Danvers, but even that cannot save this film from mediocrity. (Truth be told, the Mrs. Danvers character is the juiciest in the story.)The worst part of the movie is how the writers have altered the denoument completely, weakening both its punch and surprise. One of the principal supporting characters, Jack Favell (portrayed by Sam Riley), is reduced to a simpering boor; his role has become almost an afterthought rather than the key on which the story turns. George Sanders and Jonathan Cake each gave masterful renditions of Favell's venality in the 1940 and 1997 versions, respectively.It is a shame that the original material has been so badly diluted.
I thought there was more to this movie than there was. Disappinting. Not worth the time spent watching it.

reviews.review_title: Not worth the 2+ hours it takes to watch it.
reviews.content: The beginning of the movie was amazing, acting was good, and it pulled you right in! However, the movie made a huge turning point once you reach the first major plot point. I almost turned it off but kept watching in hopes there would be a big revel, that never really came. By the end I felt as though I had watched two entirely different movies with no real resolution, and even the protagonists weren't really likable. I'm going to read the book and hope for a better ending.
DuMaurier deserves so much better. Why even attempt to remake a Hitchcock masterpiece if all you're bringing is the latest set of Hollywood teeth?!
I have zero idea why they made this movie! Kinda boring..strange scenes..unlikeable characters. Dumb ending.

Lots to like here, supporting cast, scenery, set design. Would have worked much better if the two leads were more than blah. Too bad, they should have been able to get "anyone they wanted," with the big Netflix budget. Not looking to measure up to Hitchcock, but come on. Glad they didn't advance it to modern times, the 30s looked great.

First and foremost - Boring. Secondly- the male lead is awful. I looked forward to seeing this remake but rather than a melodramatic romantic tale one gets a series of scenes. The whole mess lacks soul. I wouldn't bother.

After reading the reviews on this movie I felt compelled to write my own. I've never read the book nor seen any similar adaptation of this and honestly I loved it. I sat down expecting an Agatha Christie like movie experience and I got it. How I thought the movie was going was nowhere near where it went. I enjoyed the characters, loving and hating them which is a display of the tremendous acting in this film. Visually it is a dark beautifully done movie with a great plot. Made me desperately want a trip to Europe and to spend the weekend watching other period themed movies and shows. Watch this movie on dark rainy night with a good bottle of wine curled up under blanket. You can thank me later.

reviews.review_title: Rebecca or The Haunting on Manderley Abbey
reviews.content: This week Netflix released a remake of an Alfred Hitchcock classic, Rebecca, that stars Lily James and Armie Hammer as the main couple at the center of the story. The film is based on a novel by Daphne du Maurier that has been on high school reading lists for decades though I've never read it or seen the Hitchcock version. I didn't know exactly what I was getting into, but I expected thrills, maybe a ghost and a tense mystery. Here's what I actually got.The basic premise of Rebecca is that a rich guy, Maxim de Winter (Hammer), falls for a young lady's companion (James) while on vacation and their swooning romance becomes an impulsive commitment. Maxim is a widower still troubled by his wife, Rebecca's death; but, he brings the new Mrs. de Winter to his estate, Maderley, where the specter of Rebecca lingers and clings to the shady housekeeper, Mrs. Danvers (Thomas). Hijinks ensue.Supposedly, there's a mystery surrounding the circumstances of Rebecca's death. We hear whispers, but get no real details. Mrs. Danvers acts very strangely and disapproving of the new Mrs. de Winter, but the sneering portrayal while good doesn't really enhance the material. Both Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas fill their roles admirably. James plays the doe-eyed rube well. She reminds me of the charm she had from her days in Downton Abbey. Thomas gets to be icy and almost menacing. Her obsession with Rebecca is palpable, but it is not really clear why she is so stuck on her - it feels just like a power trip. Hammer just fills the role of window dressing - any actor could have played that part. He and Lily James do look good together and have some good moments, but she gets the credit for selling the romance aspect of this film.The look of Rebecca is really well done though. Manderley is a stunning estate inside and out. It has that English stateliness of a Downton Abbey, but it also is creepy - too big to be cozy and so many rooms. There are shots that are on cliffs that are beautiful and scary at once. The sprawl of all that is going on fills the screen so wonderfully. They really spent their money well on that aspect. If the plot were as interesting as the craft of the film, then this would be a real winner.Ultimately, Rebecca is a passable film for 2 hours. It is not entirely engrossing, but it isn't boring either. It takes a while to get to the point and for the mystery to develop, but even then, it feels like an afterthought. On a gloomy autumn evening, you could do worse with a handful of popcorn than watch Rebecca. Give it a try.

reviews.review_title: Visually pleasing, isolated good acting, and Lily James (who alone may be reason enough for some)
reviews.content:
Daphne du Maurier's best-seller "Rebecca" has been adapted many times over the years via different media (radio, TV, movie). Best known is the 1940 movie directed by Alfred Hitchcock, starring Joan Fontaine and Laurence Olivier. This latest, 2020 version comes with top-notch art direction, breath-taking set design and vacation-brochure-like scenery. Many people, I believe, want to see it just for Lily James. What it lacks is the gruelling tension and dark subtleties expected of the original novel. Let's, stay away from comparing and pretend that it is the first time we hear this story.
As in the originals, Lily James's character's maiden name is not revealed. Until she marries Maxim de Winter (Armie Hammer) nobody addresses her by any name. Then, she becomes "Mrs. de Winter" to everybody, taking over the name of the previous owner Rebecca, who was drowned in a capsized boat six months ago.
There is a cast of strong supporting actors. Let me introduce them as they appear, in succession, as the narrative unfolds.
The movie opens with Mrs. de Winter's VO, uttering the immortal line from the story "I dream I was is Manderley again". The first sequences, which takes her from Monte Carlo to Manderley, can be considered a prelude. In these scenes, we may have seen the best of the supporting performances, from Ann Dowd playing Mrs. Van Hopper who employs her as a "lady's companion", a sort of glorified travelling housemaid. Those who have seen the mesmerising TV series "The Leftovers" know how good she is. As the nasty Mrs. Van Hopper, Dowd steals every scene she is in. Unfortunately, we see no more of her after the lucky girl's brief romance encounter with Maxim. Off they go Manderley.
"Gothic" appears to be the word legally required to describe any terror-imposing mansion, although the degree of "Gothic-ness" varies. Manderley in this movie is on the mild end of the scale, if only judged by the light palette of its exterior. The first of the support cast we meet there is Tom Goodman-Hill, who has a proliferation of 106 acting credits under his name. Here, he plays Frank, the good-natured cousin who can always be relied upon.
The next one that appears I hesitate to categorize as "support". This is none other than Kristin Scott Thomas, playing Mrs. Danvers, the darkly menacing Manderley-keeper who had also been something like a surrogate mother to Rebecca. "Danny" deserves to be consider one of the three leads in this movie rather than a support character.
Two more characters complete my list. Mrs de Winter soon meets Beatrice, her friendly and reassuring sister-in-law, played by Keeley Hawes. While this seasoned British actress is not exactly a household name, those who have seen the compelling TV series "Bodyguard" will not forget her as the high profile Home Secretary, even though she appears in only the first 3 episodes of the 7-episode mini-series. Completing the list is Rebecca's loathsome cousin Jack Favell, who appears at the mid-point of the movie. He is played by Sam Riley, who plays the lovable lackey Diaval (with an altered ego as a crow) to Maleficent (Angelina Jolie).

Spectacularly underwhelming. Rebecca is style over substance from start to finish. And while the style is nice, that's where the good things end. There is nothing in this film that made me care about it.I'm still struggling to figure out what this movie was trying to be. It started as a thriller, nearing horror at times with its haunted house setting. Then it moved more towards being a love drama, after which it tried to turn into a murder mystery. There was so much going on, that it's no wonder that none of it worked. I liked the idea of the haunted house, but it never managed to be scary. It never managed to be even remotely tense. Things happened without any consequence or meaning.
And as for the rest of the movie, there is very little to say about it. The film jumps from one genre and idea to another so quickly that it becomes impossible to follow any intention that the film had, let alone care about it.Another thing that really bothered me was the characters. There wasn't a single one that I liked. Perhaps that is the case in the source material as well but in the context of this movie, having no one to care about made it impossible to care about the movie. The film tried to make me invested with an incredibly drawn-out sequence in the beginning, but it managed to make zero impact. By the end of it, I cared just as little about the characters as I did in the beginning. Which, as far as I'm concerned, is a bit of an issue in a movie that is completely character-driven.But it wasn't all bad. As mentioned, Rebecca very clearly prioritized style over substance. Thankfully the style worked. It was a very nice looking film. It was obvious that a lot of care had been taken to get the setting and mood right. Unfortunately, style and visuals can only get you so far. Had the film managed to make me care even in the slightest, the visuals would've made it a much better experience than it had any right to be. But as is, the look of the film gets drowned out by the mess that is the rest of the film.The biggest problem is that Rebecca tries to be too many things at the same time. As a result, everything ends up feeling watered down and shallow. There is no central thread that the viewer can grab onto, nor does it give you any reason to care about it. And no matter how nice the visuals and the look of the film are, they aren't enough to pull this film out of the mess it made of itself.

Daphne du Maurier's novel Rebecca is a masterpiece. David O. Selznick knew that when people came to see his version directed by Alfred Hitchcock, they would want to see the book. He did the same with Gone With the Wind. Even Hitchcock wanted to change some things but Selznick stuck to his guns and the movie was a huge success and won the Oscar for Best Picture in 1940. So 80 years later, this remake comes to the screen. It started out okay. quoting the classic first line of the book, "Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again." I decided I would not compare it to the Hitchcock movie but rather the novel on which it is based. They stayed fairly true to the book with occasional weird moments added in. Then it all fell apart. I won't spoil anything, but where there was so much suspense in the book, here it became rather bland and unemotional. The ending was completely changed and the last scene was total sleaze. I assume it was meant to be politically correct but are you kidding me? Anyway, thought Lily James did well in the role until her 'transformation" but that was more the directors fault than hers. Mr. Hammer is wooden and dull. Maxim de Winter is not a very likeable character in the book but he is played here like a Casper Milktoast. Ms. Scott-Thomas does well as Mrs. Danvers. Overall, could have been so much better. I agree with Mr. Selznick. People want to see the book.

This was a gothic style thriller..... ruined. A weird mix of periods, set out of time. The cinematography was appalling modern at some points and oddly retro at others. The often mesmeric Scott-Thomas was wasted and the rest made Eastenders cast appear Oscar worthy.
What the hell were they thinking. All the way through this I was going "what have they done" and "how bad can it be" - fairly bad.

reviews.review_title: Poor script sinks a great director and it is shameful waste of that man's talent
reviews.content: Another clunky script from Goldman that was unengaging without mystery, intrigue or suspense.The most criminal thing about this whole affair is the wasted talents of Ben Wheatley. The guy made the amazingly inventive and unsettling A Field in England. Why he decided to take this on i dont know because there is clearly no passion there from his point of view. We see a very small glimpse of his dynamic style at the ball but this is all otherwise is a nuts n bolts affair.The performance are all fine but nothing outstanding or interesting. The score is your bog standard dramatic string arrangements. The story is dull and plods along in heavy steps with so much expositions it becomes patronising quite honestly.Kristin Scott Thomas gets a star and the first act was ok but overall disappointing. Please Mr Wheatley make something original next time that you have written.
Beautifully designed and atmospheric, this elegant but uneven remake of the Hitchcock classic is able to deliver a few chills and thrills despite its script exaggerating flaws.
Start a movie with overbearing music and a woman whispering the set up premise and I'm out!

reviews.content:
I get that when you are turning a book into a film you have to cut a lot out and make things go quicker but every part of this story was rushed.
I was so excited to watch this but now so disappointed
