reviews.content: I actually enjoy this movie with the music, cinematography, and the performance of the casts.. Maybe people still compare this movie with The Hitchcock Movie, but actually it was different.. Ben Wheatley's opinion was right, he is not making remake of Hitchcock's movie which is masterpiece, but it his adaptation of the novel.
An easy to watch version that sits alongside classics. Very in your face with the subtext, but that's ok

The 2020 Rebecca is such a huge let-down not to merit a review. It fails in all departments of movie making. Shoddy is the word. The literary classic is translated on screen by great Hitchcock in 1940 and acted by thespian Sir Laurence Olivier. The new Rebecca is no match

reviews.review_title: I would frankly use the work 'crime'...against the Cinema!
reviews.content:
Its'a a crime. Not against Hitchcock, but against Daphne Du Maurier's story and its characters, against cinema, and against good taste.
First, the people who wrote this haven't understood the story.
There should be an age difference between Maxim and the new Mrs. de Winter. That's important because they are not supoposed to understand each other completely before Rebecca's body is discovered.
Instead of speaking freely and asking bluntly "how did your wife die" in the first meeting, she is supposedly shy, not experienced, but well educated. She comes, however, from a different social standing and - no - this is not a question of "discrimination"! That's simply how it was. And in the film - and I think the novel - she is not barred from the terrace of the hotel: she is simply sitting at another table, net to Maxim!..
The woman playing Mrs Van Hopper is a disaster!!! She looks like an old drunken hippie, and absolutely not like a 1930's american millionnaire. The scene where she mocks the girl with her friends or acquaintances is in terrible bad taste and unthinkable. Also unnecessary.
If you make a 1930's movie, it's not just about cars and dresses. You have to understand the mentality. And that mentality is a very important part of this story!!!
Also, girls wouldn't know about 3.5 liters Bentleys "because her father liked cars"!
The whole thing is a disaster. The one star I gave the movie is for Armie Hammer, the only one who seems to know more or less what he's doing, though he seems to be drowning in an Ocean of stupidity!
Like someone else said: if you can't do any better, you'd better do nothing!!! Or ask someone who knows something about it!!!

reviews.review_title: I Liked This Version Much Better Than Hitchcock
reviews.content: Sorry, I love old movies, but the Hitchcock version was just plain corny and rushedLike a lot of those films back in the day the romance to marriage was always rushed (you had to be married to have sex, oh my!).And like most of the portrayals of women in movies back then, the women were always selfless and spent most of her time simpering and whimpering and trying to please her man, even if he was a cad.Yes, I know the film may have been like the book or of the times, but that part of old films always annoyed me, because we know the scandals and nothing is new under the sun.Anyway, I found this version a little more modern and charming and the acting a lot better than the stiff acting, over-acting, and histrionics that marred so many of the movies from the 30'and 40's.

First of all, I have not seen the original movie. Therefore, I think I could enjoy this version in an unbiased way. However, looking at the reviews here, I don't think that was the case for most reviewers who have made comparisons with the original. For someone who knew nothing about the Hitchcock's original, all I can say is that I thoroughly enjoyed this movie from the beginning to the end on a Saturday night. Especially, the cinematography was impressive and it managed to keep me intrigued throughout its runtime. I am planning to watch the original at some point and I know I might change my opinion on this on then. However, I'd say if you have not seen the original, just ignore the negative reviews here. I am pretty sure you will enjoy this one.
Reasonable, Kirstin Scott-Thomas is great. Script follows the book. Not very exciting, but good enough for simple fridaynight entertainment

I don't understand the hate. it's visually dazzling. the acting is good. it's a great thriller and romance combined. it's not really confusing. i guess it's not meant for everyone. if you like thriller/romance this is good. i love lily james and i think this was a good role for her, armie was good as well. it's not the best film but it's still good and i would recommend it! it's a perfect amount of spookiness. it might be more enjoyable for people who have not read the book or seen the original film and i'm saying this because there are a few changes made and i think people who love the book or original film just weren't expecting changes.

Ignore the harsh critics. This is a well-crafted film that deftly blends the beautiful and the dark gothic with skill and vision. Please understand that this is a film adaptation of the novel by 20th C gothic writer Daphne du Maurier--it is not a "Hitchcock remake" as others claim. And you really need to read the book to appreciate some of the subtleties of this film and its depiction of the narrative.
Some of the criticisms of the film are really about the novel itself. While perhaps Armie is a bit young to play Maxim, he did a marvelous job of conveying Maxim's inner demons which drove his mercurial nature that could be warm one moment and cold the next. I thought there was great chemistry with Hammer and James-a little more subtle than what some reviewers here wanted, but that is the way the book was written. DuMaurier writes their marriage as a bit paternalistic and refined but still loving and supportive (not Cathy-and-Heathcliff-combustion). The actors and director did a very good job of echoing that relationship with a little more passion thrown in for modern tastes. Lily James is perfect for the doe-eyed, ingenue role, and although at times her mousy, nervous deference was annoying, it's pretty darn close to the novel's depiction of her character. The show-stealer, though, was Kristin Scott Thomas who played her role of the sinister Ms. Danvers with frighteningly steely perfection. It's hard to make KST look unappealing, but the severity of her appearance and mannerisms here reflected the troubled darkness lurking beneath her polished veneer and wry, artificial smile. Brilliant performance.
What I really appreciated about this film was the incredible attention to detail and emphasis on the house as a reflection of the narrative. Everything from the ivy-patterned bed linens (invasive, suffocating, creeping) to the image of new Mrs.DeWinter blending in to the landscape in an ill-fitting green coat that was Rebecca's (she is disappearing in a role she does not fit) to the staff looking past her as they walk by (she is now the ghost in Manderlay), shows a thoughtful effort to visually echo the narrative tension. The cinematography-esp. the play of shadow vs light and dark/grey vs vibrant color- and the opulent sets and exotic locations make this film a feast for the eyes.
I don't agree with others who feel the second half was rushed. I wish the movie had been longer to allow for more development with some characters and plotlines, but it's very difficult to portray this complex, twisting story in a short period of time. Overall, it was an enjoyable film that I'll watch again. Just remember to view the film through the lens of an 82-yr-old novel, not a modern script.

reviews.review_title: Skip this for moral and artistic reasons.
reviews.content: The main male lead is a souless husk, and also abuses women in real life! So skip it for that, but also this adaption shreds the tension and art of the original book.If you want to watch a movie adaption, watch Hitchcock's version.

If you don't understand Rebecca then please don't make a movie about it. Whoever made the movie doesn't have the slightest clue who Rebecca really was. How could you alter Rebecca's death scene?!!! It embodies the very soul of her personality.

reviews.review_title: A poor initiation of an average original
reviews.content:
I was astounded that this was a Ben Wheatley film.
Arnie Hammer is at least not the dreadful Olivier.
Mrs Dr Winter continues to be tiresomely simpering.
Mrs Danvers remains the only one having any fun.
There's probably scope to do a really good contemporary update.
Wasted opportunity.

I wish they'd changed the period as I found both Armie Hammer and Lily James rather stiff and flat. It would have been interesting if they'd moved it to the 1950s and rewritten the story. This was almost a pointless copy of the original but lacking all the creepy suspense and charm.

This movie was a total bore. As they say, dont touch a classic and nobody can match Alfred Hitchcock's genius style. Nobody but maybe Park Chan Wook. Firstly, actors that are sub par. Armie Hammer and Lily Cole are no Laurence Olivier and Joan Fontaine.Anyway, I have never been so un-entertained. I give it one star for the excellent casting of the forever amazing Kristin Scott Thomas who saved whatever could be saved of this faithful to the book but weak dull movie.

reviews.review_title: Crisp And Exiting New Version A Must See
reviews.content: RebeccaA very good realisation of the novel and of course very different from the Alfred Hitchcock version of 1940.The movie made more of the courtship before arriving at Mandalay, this was not any bad thing, but had the effect of down playing Mrs Danvers machinations against the new Mrs DeWinter. The last 30 minutes appeared rushed and we didn't really sense what a monster Rebecca must have been.The cinematography and styling were great but the accompanying folk music was both out of place and even intrusive.Of course they changed the ending a little but overall this was a really great movie, a hard seven.

reviews.review_title: So much better than I expected.
reviews.content: Whatever you do, don't approach Ben Wheatley's new film "Rebecca" as a remake of Alfred Hitchcock's much beloved classic, not that it ever would have been; Wheatley is his own man and we always knew he would do things differently, in this case sticking more closely to the book and casting it in such a way as to banish all memories of Fontaine, Olivier and Dame Judith and in this he has been largely successful. Armie Hammer is a lot less melancholy, if a tad modern, than Lord Larry ever was. Lily James is much more down-to-earth and obviously a good deal more sensual than Joan while Kristin Scott Thomas gives Mrs. Danvers a human side that was totally lacking in Judith Anderson's performance. Indeed, regardless of what else you think of the film I doubt if anyone could find fault with Scott Thomas who effortlessly walks away with the picture.It also benefits from a Manderley that really looks like it might be one of the finest houses in all of England and the whole thing is beautifully shot by Laurie Rose in widescreen and colour. Fans of Mr. Hitchcock's version are unlikely to be won over; however, newcomers and fans of Du Maurier's novel should find plenty here to please them though the device of not giving the new Mrs. De Winter a Christian name seems even more contrived this time round.

I think that in order to enjoy this film it is essential that you haven't seen the original. I have and found this virtually unwatchable. It lacks any weight, tension or gravitas. Completely unnecessary remake and disappointing on every level.

I loved everything about this movie. The cast is literally "chef's kiss". The leads, Armie Hammer and Lily James share crackling chemistry. A beautiful-to-look-at pair. Kristin Scott Thomas was phenomenal.
The cinematography, the background score and strong performances made this movie a must watch.
5/5
I loved Armie Hammer and so was very disappointed by this movie. There was little intrigue and no narrative. Bland, boring and utterly forgettable!

reviews.review_title: Du Maurier fans: consider it a comedy
reviews.content: This is a very expensive and stylish adaptation, a real treat for the eyes. But as a big du Maurier fan, I was angered the first time I saw it. It improves on subsequent viewings.As usual, they cast a beautiful blonde as the nameless heroine. We could live with that, but she is loaded with agency. She demands unconventional breakfasts of the waiters in Monte Carlo, she has an anachronistically revealing bathing suit, she even tells Mrs. Danvers to scram. Twice.They do it, or something that looks awfully like it, before they are married. Mrs. Van Hopper finds out about their romance from gossips. Mrs. Danvers calls Rebecca-and Frank Crawley-by their first names. Maxim writes Jack Favell a check for 10,000 pounds, and Favell decides not to cash it, but to turn it over to the proper authorities. Perhaps funniest of all, when the heroine realizes the importance of Dr. Baker, she jumps in the car by herself, drives hundreds of miles to London, uses subterfuge to get into Dr. Baker's office, and steals Rebecca's medical record. Get the picture? Enjoy the scenery, be glad that a new generation has been introduced to du Maurier, and don't become too angry at the weirdness.

A bright screen where drops of darkness fall over time, which it seems is not. Causing an unexpected twist. Photography and environment of great class and aesthetic beauty. Good performances, I liked and recommend.

Something was missing and I just can not put my finger on it. May be it felt a bit too rushed, may be the element of mystery wasn't captured as it should have been, may be the lead character wasn't just as strong as I expected it to be, or may be all of them put together. I know it's not fair to compare the movie with the book, but I can not help it. It should have been a series than a two hours movie. There was so much more to this than was presented.
Something to pass the time or a waste of time. I really can't decide.

Why was this film even made? So poorly realised and surprisingly boring. I liked the actors cast but they didn't stand a chance in this terrible retelling of a classic novel. Read the book, this terrible film is but a shadow of the original tale.

reviews.review_title: Not Bad for A Free Watch, but...
reviews.content: Editing/pacing was strange; very choppy. Armie Hammer was not mature enough to portray Maxim De Winter. Kristin Scott Thomas and Keely Hawes do not much resemble each other in real life but their characters in the film resembled each other way too much. Some odd directorial and storyline choices, neither adhering to any of the previous film adaptations, nor to the novel. Glossed over many important parts, including the turning point of the story...like commenting on the consistency of the morning porridge...as well as missing some great opportunities. The last 20 minutes was so rushed and disjointed as to be just silly. Definitely not of the same caliber as the Hitchcock interpretation nor of the same gothic weight as the novel.

Don't pay attention to the bad reviews. For the ones who haven't seen the old movie this can be a really enjoyable one. It's full of mysteries and suspense. Give it a try! I get bored very easily, but this movie got me entertained the whole two hours.
I think all the haters are Hitchcock's fans, and I understand that the old movie might be better, but this one is good too.

reviews.review_title: Don't let the bad reviews keep you from watching!
reviews.content: I have never seen the movie that this was a remake of. It was just a new Netflix movie. Pretty good I must say! Kept me on the edge of my seat wanting to know things but also things were not expected. Watch it!

Rebecca: This is not a horror film but with Ben Wheatley at the helm as Director you can be sure of a dark adaptation of Daphne du Maurier's classic novel. Lily James is the new Mrs de Winter and from her first arrival at Manderley ,the housekeeper Mrs Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas), makes her feel as if she is usurping the late Rebecca de Winter. Gaslighting of James continues, especially at the Ball she organises. Rebecca may be dead but her presence rules over the house. The film opens in Monte Carlo where James is a companion to a wealthy American, Mrs Van Hopper. The feel and cinematography at this stage is reminiscent of The Talented Mr Ripley. While James is no imposter she does suffer from imposter syndrome. When Maxim de Winter (Arnie Hammer) sweeps her off her feet and proposes marriage, Mrs Van Hopper tells her she is just a passing interest for him. This makes Danvers work all the easier. Wheatley has delivered a Gothic movie which touches on horror at times but the pacing is off. Too much is crammed into the second half of Rebecca with the all important revelations coming at us too quickly. It may not achieve classic status but it is both intriguing and entertaining. On Netflix. 8/10.
Very decent movie. Interesting story about a man that was terrorized by a manipulative woman. A movie about complicated and destructive women.

reviews.review_title: Reading Rebecca is far better than watching Rebecca
reviews.content: The storyline in the book was rich with how each character identified its existance.Very few almost to rare depictions of main punchlines within the book in the movie. I enjoyed reading and letting my imagination create the scenes more than watching them..

reviews.review_title: A bit intense at the end, but overall full of boring conversation, and annoying overuse scene! Should have done better!
reviews.content: This film start with the narrator talking about the manor "Manderley", and her employer "Van Hopper" scene! As turnout, this film is about solving the mystery of the death of Rebecca! Rebecca actually kill by her husband "Maxim", but eventually overturn by suicide! Entire film full of boring conversation, and annoying overuse scene! Such as, overuse of the annoying song playing at the background scene, overuse of the dreaming scene, overuse of the kissing scene, overuse the passing note scene, and overuse of the dining scene! Make the film unwatchable! Barely intense scene is, Manderley been burned by Mrs. Danvers at the end! At the end, Maxim release from the jail after proving Rebecca kill herself by Mrs. de Winter! Maxim and Mrs. de Winter move to Cairo at the very end! That's it! Another disappointed film!

I didnt clock at first that this was a take on the novel. However, it was a more modern adaptation, although not current modern if that makes sense. I liked the casting and the intrigue. Definitely worth a watch.

Oh dear, this was not good and the acting terrible with the exception of the wonderful Kristin Scott Thomas as Mrs Danvers. I don't see the point in watching this when you can just watch the original Hitchcock movie which is movie genius!

This dull, plodding story coasts to its end without magic and, worse yet, without style. The camera, shockingly, does not love the lead actors. James plays a date of some experience, not a star-struck innocent. Their romantic beach scenes played to today's audience, not the reality of 1935. Hammer, appallingly dressed in a wrinkled, ugly brown suit in 1935 Monte Carlo, lacks the needed imperious nature of an English titled gentleman. Scott Thomas lacks menace. The story has been considerably changed either out of ignorance or to fit the time constraints. This movie either suffers from misdirection or poor cinematography. Or both. I would highly recommend the 1998 version of Rebecca starring Charles Dance and Emilia Fox if you want to see the best, magical version.

reviews.review_title: Not Hitchcock and not apologetic about it. A whole different, much more gripping and thorough interpretation to the base material
reviews.content:
Absolutely amazing. Haven't seen a movie like that in a long time. A real movie. It was so full of life. From the aesthetics, to the tone of writing that was so stylish, to the overall sense of directing and the feeling of a unique world condensed into a screen
From the design of the opening credits, the opening monologue(loved Lily's accent btw). And then a line of great actresses began. Lily that starts as that awkward girl, goes through being terrorized and to the end when she really develops as a person. The first one that caught my eye was the eccentric character played by Ann Dowd. She was addictive and so much fun and intense, plus she had amazing overall aesthetic.
Then you have some gorgeous but very subtle/short romantic intimate scenes. As much as subtle/short as they were, they really left a feeling, and helped keep in mind and believe what the two characters felt about each other and how that really fueled their motives. Jane lapotaire(a favorite of mine from the crown) had one scene, sort of a cameo, but was amazing and so added to the building sense of psychological thriller that's going on. Kristin Scott Thomas started to show small nuances of her complex character, unique traits of how she presents herself etc, and was so impressive and fun as the movie kept going. Always fond of the psycho-biddies, but Kristin really gave her depth and made her emotions so human and bold. on top of that the wonderful Lesley hawes who played such a lovable good hearted character you could not help but really fall for her.
As the movie proceeded the tension grew, but in peaks, which was very interesting, really felt it at some points(reminded me of Darren aronofsky's mother! For few scenes).
I just loved how Rebecca and her role was interpreted and used so differently from the Hitchcock's version. Taken much more to depth and played with! Explored! What it did to mrs de winter. The the name Rebecca appeared on everything and haunted the viewers as sort of a replacement to the usual monsters who follow and chase the victim. The suspense was amazing, especially towards the end.
I feel like this is a story with so much to it. And this movie really dived in.
A filmmaker I'm so excited to follow as he starts his journey. Absolutely a talent that made a strong piece. Some of you might've not liked it. But I know in the future if he gets a material that's more to your liking, he'll know what to do with it.
Perfect length, did not at all get me bored like the Hitchcock one did! Was absolutely gripping till the last second actually. And just the transformation of lily was so beautiful and smart, crafted carefully and believably.
I will say one thing I disliked- the CGI'd scenes that were unnecessary, not very well done, and undermined the general aesthetic and at atmosphere. But that is so small in comparison to how amazing it is all together.
So I'll just say I enjoyed it so much and will watch again in the future.

It wafts along like a bad smell. Nothing really happens. There are boring conversations about nothing with little to know depth to the acting. Go back and watch the films of the 1940s, the classics. They often had so much substance and depth and this one is an example of that.
Because it was far more opulent that the previous black and white version. And it's more explainable and detailed also.

This movie had potential to be way better. More background into the life of Rebecca would have Made the storyline more interesting in the later stage of the film. I found the new Mrs De Winter quite irritating at first and thought that her transition into her new self at the end could have been further developed. The house keeper was the most interesting character and her sly nature was evident and almost understandable in the end

Having read the Daphne Du Maurier's novel and Hitchcock's version of it, I must say that none of the cinema versions, including this, come close to the novel.In this version, Christin Scott Thomas has none of the incipient evil of Judith Sanderson's portrayal of Mrs Danvers in Hitchcock's envision and Lilly James has none of the gauche innocence of Joan Fontaine in Hitchcock's version, nor the novel.The denouement fails to capture the climax of the novel, in which there is no mention of Mrs Danver's involvement in the destruction of of Manderley, nor her demise.Inspector Welch is given far more credit than the novel portrays, and
the discovery of Rebecca's illness is glossed over, with Welch given too much credit for the discovery.As a stand alone it is watchable, but for anyone who has read the novel or seen the earlier cinematic versions it is a poor substitute.
The whole movie was ruined by a ridiculously week ending. I literally felt robbed of a proper ending

Don't know what's up with all these haters, they probably just don't enjoy a good story. That's all the movie is. Just a good story. Something enjoyable to watch on a Sunday evening while light rain can be heard inside your living room. So go ahead and curl up with your favorite person. Get a bag of popcorn and some delicious drinks.

reviews.review_title: What is this supposed to be?
reviews.content:
This is one of the most ridiculous things I've ever seen in my life.
What were they thinking?
It's painful to watch.
Why just why???

This remake of Alfred Hitchcock's only Oscar win is a travesty. I have never been so insulted by such lazy film making and writing as this. Armie Hammer in pastel linen suits couldn't even give this more than 2 Stars.

I have not watched the original movie, so everything was a twist for me. Plus it was beautifully shot with gorgeous sceneries and decors. The main female character was annoying, but I suppose that was her role.

That's the sound of this version losing steam just before the end, relative to Hitchcock's 1940 Academy Award winner.
Otherwise, that's the worst I can say about it. Good presentation of the much-loved, much adapted classic novel.
There are nightmarish bits and sequences added here that are not in the earlier film which are on the one hand a novel and original insertion but maybe ultimately gimmicky in their excess, as The New Mrs de Winter's waking life is more terrifying than the relative insubstantiality of mere dreams. There are no glimpses of Rebecca's ghost running down corridors in Hitchcock, yet her presence is constantly, oppressively. almost palpably present.
Another thing this really has going for it is inclusion of the novel's key plot point, which Hitchcock could not use due to the moral prohibitions of the Hollywood Code then in place, but if anyone could pull off getting round that it was Hitchcock and a stellar team of screenplay writers and adapters
Armie Hammer certainly looks the part of a 1930's aristocratic millionaire hunk but lacks the fire of Olivier's impassioned performance. Lily James gives an admirable current day performance, almost the performance Joan Fontaine would have given if she were a contemporary actress in our contemporary cinema. Ann Dowd as the future New Mrs. de Winter's former protectress/employer, an affected Grande Dame spinster is equally delightfully detestable as 1940's great character actress Florence Bates. 1940's George Sanders is simply irreplaceable in any role he ever took, but Sam Riley manages to hold his own doing it his own way.
Then there's Kristin Scott-Thomas. If anyone was ever up to attempting a role Dame Judith Anderson made a byword, it's her, although Agnes Moorehead did it in a radio adaptation, which also has to be entered in the competition for who did it best. Not blessed, in this case, with the Dame's renowned, shall we say, lack of beauty, instead Ms Scott-Thomas compensates by breathing all the more fiery venom, while remaining chillingly cool as a cucumber tea sandwich. She exudes the air of an evil Mary Poppins FROM HELL! .
Two BIG plusses for Hitchcock's: Franz Waxman's soaring score, and George Barnes Oscar-winning Beautiful B&W cinematography. Totally dark black shadows and unlit corridors draw and compel while simultaneously inducing terrible and inescapable fear, something random hues from a prism, no matter how dim, never can.
Back to the end, I know the original novelist Daphne Du Maurier wrote one ending for the book, and another for her own adaptation for a dramatic presentation, but did no work on any other of the film/radio/tv projects based on "Rebecca". I've never read the book, only seen the 1940 and 2020 movies, so have no idea if these follow either of her endings, but for me, between the two options presented by these two films, a Fiery End makes an incomparable impression compared to a soggy dunk in the Deep .

I thought the secondary actors were very well casted.
The score was a great contribution to the movie in my opinion!
The cinematography was mostly good, with great use of colors at times, unfortunately there were times where it was a bit dull.
I also felt the ending was rushed and fragmented, with the last minutes of the movie being quite disappointing.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as the critics say
reviews.content: This glossy new version of "Rebecca," based on the late Daphne du Maurier's hit novel, was entertaining, if flawed due to some of the performances and pacing. The costumes, scenery and sets, particularly in the South of France and the main characters' lavish Cornwall estate, Manderley. Lily James is beautiful, but tends to overact, or perhaps she seems to use the same expressions and emotions in every role? "Rebecca" is meant to be very melodramatic, and her character is suffering through emotional anguish due to some nasty gaslighting by Manderley's dastardly housekeeper, Mrs. Danvers (played with razor-sharp glee by Kristin Scott-Thomas, who steals the show in the showiest role--and pulls no punches), so perhaps James' hair-pulling and blouse-clutching makes sense. She lays it on a little thick, even though "Rebecca" is set in the 1930s when young, middle-class English women would have been more naive and impressionable, not so sophisticated or feisty as modern women. Armie Hammer looks gorgeous and terribly pained as Maxim de Winter, but I'm not sure he has a great deal of chemistry with James. The early scenes in the Cote d'Azur were the most compelling part, not only for the lush scenery (who wouldn't fall in love in such a setting?), but the depiction of how the two main characters kindle their romance.I wonder if a story like "Rebecca" is just too hokey and old-fashioned for contemporary movie audiences. Can 21st century women relate to an unnamed ingenue who's out of her depth as the mistress of a huge English country estate, selecting sauces for the beef, directing the staff, and planning lavish costume balls? Not to mention dealing with a super-toxic housekeeper and a distant, aristocratic hubby? I have seen the classic 1940 version of "Rebecca," directed by Alfred Hitchcock, and I agree that Joan Fontaine and Laurence Olivier had more chemistry than version's stars, and Hitchcock's pacing really amped up the tension. But the main drawback may just be that "Rebecca" is a hokey old story that doesn't age so well.
It made me miss Hitchcock so much. Mystery a little and Romance yes.

reviews.review_title: Netflix's version of Rebecca is... weird.
reviews.content: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free reviews, please follow my blog :)Netflix's Rebecca is based on the 1938's novel of the same name written by Daphne du Maurier, but it's not its first cinematic adaptation, which leads me to the following shameful statement: I've never seen the famous Alfred Hitchcock's version of this story (nor have I read the novel, but I firmly defend that this doesn't matter). It's the only film of Hitchcock's filmography to have received the Best Picture award, so I admit that I'm much at fault here. However, Ben Wheatley isn't directing a remake of the original movie, but rather another adaptation of the also incredibly popular novel. I was intrigued by the premise, and the cast is definitely convincing, so how did it go?If I had to choose one word to ultimately describe Rebecca right now, it would probably be... weird. More on this in a bit. Starting with the positives, Armie Hammer and Lily James share such vivid chemistry that it elevates the surprisingly compelling bond that their characters form. I write "surprisingly" because I'm not easily engaged in most romantic relationships in films, whether these are straight-up romances or mixed up with other genres, like comedy or, as in this case, horror/thriller. Nevertheless, Lily and Armie are able to capture perfectly the growing love interest in one another through the first act, which is entirely dedicated to develop and nurture the key relationship of the movie.This is something I sincerely appreciate: when filmmakers know how to control pacing and how much time should a particular character or storyline receive of build-up. Wheatley does an impressive job during the first half of the film by moving the characters and plot forward at the precise moment they need to. This allows the viewer to understand what the characters are genuinely feeling and why some narrative decisions are made that change the course of the story. Lily James offers a remarkable performance, just like Armie Hammer. Kristin Scott Thomas is also excellent, even though her character is part of my problems with the movie. However, it's the production design that stands out!The beautiful colors and striking landscapes of the French Riviera fill the screen with luxury and harmony during the naturally passionate beginning of the relationship. Once the narrative moves to Manderley, the tone changes to a gradually more depressing, dark environment, accompanied by a creepy score (Clint Mansell), and spooky nightmares. The adequate costumes also help to set the atmosphere, but the beginning of the second half is where things start to get extremely weird.From the very first moment the viewer sets place in Manderley, something is noticeably not right. Everyone addresses the late wife, Rebecca, as the most perfect human being to ever exist, reaching God-like compliments in a clear attempt of trying to create the cliche "previous wife was amazing, new one is awful, let's make her life a living hell" storyline. An expected development with exaggeratedly positive comments from the staff. However, it's the horror vibe that embraces the mansion that drives me nuts. Wheatley sets a dark, mysterious, even supernatural environment surrounding the house, a definitely intriguing aspect that leads to a hugely disappointing, hollow, unsatisfactory conclusion.From the first to the second act, the genre in display changes from a fun, lighthearted romance to a horror/thriller featuring a "haunted" mansion. The tone change is far from being smooth. However, the third act stores a drastic shift in pretty much everything: tone, genre, story, and even characters. I can't get into details, but it's the most incomprehensible decision in the entire film. The last act not only follows a path that comes from nowhere, but it's also incredibly rushed, concluding the movie in the most disjointed, convoluted way possible.It raises questions related to events and characters in the previous act, it treats Mrs. Danvers very poorly, and ends with a deceiving last shot that makes the viewer think "did I miss something?" when the answer is a clear "no, it's just a weird ending". Clint Mansell's score is captivating, but its timing is just completely off. It's this feeling of false uncertainty that leaves me frustrated. Why try to make a film about something that it's not? Why try to give Rebecca a horror vibe if it doesn't lead to any impactful outcome? I finished the movie with doubts that have no reason to exist simply because the question should have never been asked by the story in the first place...All in all, Netflix's version of Rebecca gets lost in trying to balance so many genres in just one film. Ben Wheatley does a great job controlling the pacing, offering enough time to develop the main characters and the core relationship. However, the tone changes are far from being well-executed, leading to an utterly absurd, rushed, convoluted last act out of nowhere that raises logical questions and leaves the viewer with a false sense of uncertainty. A well-structured, entertaining first half partially compensates for the weirdness that overflows the second part. Lily James and Armie Hammer deliver great performances, as does Kristin Scott Thomas, but the production design (supported by terrific costumes) steals the spotlight. Clint Mansell's score doesn't go unnoticed, but its placement is exceptionally inefficient. In the end, the attempt at creating a horror atmosphere with the "haunted" mansion storyline is so anti-climactic that I can't wholeheartedly recommend this flick...Rating: C

reviews.review_title: Daphne du Maurier would be Proud
reviews.content: Let me begin by saying that 'Rebecca' is one of my favorite novels of all time, and Hitchcock's classic rendition is one of my favorite films. When I saw that Netflix had revamped it into a brand new movie, I wasn't sure what to think. Netflix has a habit of rushing their pictures and focusing more on set design and special effects than scripting and plot. However, I buckled down to watch it, and let me say, I was quite pleased and incredibly impressed.For those who don't know the story, 'Rebecca' is about a young servant to a wealthy and eccentric old woman who happens to be in the right place at the right time to find love and excitement with a wealthy and recently widowed playboy. The servant in this feature is played by the lovely and talented Lily James, and the playboy is well-cast as Armie Hammer.When the two meet and their relationship builds, there comes a bit of jealousy from the eccentric old woman, played by the always stunning Ann Dowd. With a threat to pull the servant away and take her across the world, as far away from the playboy as possible, Maxim de Winter proposes and steals the servant away, marrying her and moving her into his enormous and elegant manor.There is one problem with this - the staff of Manderley was overly fond of Rebecca, de Winter's first wife, and they do not take to Lily James all that well. In fact, the head of the house Mrs. Danvers (played by the remarkable Kristin Scott Thomas) detests the new wife's presence so much that she begins to sabotage her stay in the house.Tensions arise and dark secrets begin to surface, causing turmoil between the new bride and her loving but distant husband. The film, in true du Maurier fashion, seamlessly begins to transform from a classic romance into a nail-biting mystery.Netflix and director Ben Wheatley took their time with this story, staying as true to the novel as possible while still paying appropriate homage to Hitchcock's film - and still making it very much their own. I recommend this movie to those who love a good romance, a good thriller, and a fantastic story. And remember - if you like the movie, you'll love the book.

reviews.review_title: Disappointing retake on a classic tale
reviews.content:
The huge budget used for this movie has meant the overall production is very lavish and it is a great pity this was not shown on the big screen - those scenes shot in France and around the English coast would have been glorious. I do remember the original which was quite low budget but was full of brooding suspense and the brilliant presence of Olivier and Fontaine. What a shame, then, that Lily James and Armie Hammer, who are such an attractive couple, failed to light up the screen. I loved Armie's English accent which was quite low key, and Lily gave a good performance, they just seemed to lack chemistry together. Which gave Kristen Scott Thomas the perfect opportunity to steal the show as the nasty Mrs Danvers. Thank goodness Keeley Hawes was on hand to give some light relief here and there, even if she seemed to be laughing at herself some of the time.
The costumes were beautiful but they were let down by a disjointed script and uneven pace. Perhaps too much was expected of this film, it is a great classic and it surely deserved better treatment.

The whole movie was haunted by a better story - that of Rebecca - the mesmerizing individual who tricked everyone in the manor into believing she loved the male lead. The story everyone eventually accepts is REALLY that the victim messed up her own boat and drowned herself, instead of simply jumping off a cliff. There are so many threads that went nowhere, including dogs barking at what seemed to be nothing (I know at one point the dog was barking at someone hidden in the boat house), but why did the dog run all the way there? This feels like it wanted to be a haunted house/horror movie. It should've been left on the drawing board.

reviews.review_title: A Very Meh Visit to Manderley
reviews.content: 'Rebecca' is one of my favorite books so I am always excited when a movie adaptation is released. This version of Rebecca missed the mark. Armie Hammer, while quite dashing in his own right, is no Laurence Olivier. He lacks some of the character's brooding sophistication and mystery and seems a bit too young for the part. (Hammer is about ten years younger than the Maxim character as written by Daphne DuMaurier.) In the book and the 1940 Hitchcock adaptation, the 20 year age difference between Max and The Second Mrs. DeWinter gave the relationship an air of old time romance and tentativeness that added to the suspense. The more obvious physical intimacy between Max and his new bride in this iteration is a surprising, interesting and not wholly unwelcome revelation but one that does not stay true to the essence of the original story. Lily James as The Second Mrs. DeWinter is respectable, as is Kristen Scott Thomas as the unhinged Mrs. Danvers but I wish they had both played their roles with more intensity. Compared to the performances by Joan Fontaine and Judith Anderson, respectively, the new takes on the characters lacked passion and wound up feeling anemic. (Anderson is downright spinechilling as Danvers in the 1940 version so I imagine her shoes are hard to fill.) This version also lacked the necessary moodiness, suspense and depth of the original, and the pacing was off. Some scenes in the beginning dragged out at the expense of more key scenes especially in the end, which felt rushed. And the ending (read: last two minutes) is AWFUL. It is a total departure from the overall tone of DuMaurier's novel. The characters go, well, completely out of character and honestly, this kind of ruins the whole film. On the upside, the scenery is lovely and there are adorable dogs in supporting roles. While it's worth watching, the 2020 version of Rebecca cannot hold a candle to Hitchcock's pre-WW2 masterpiece. I don't care to go back to this Manderley again.

I couldn't imagine anyone playing the role any better than he.Here's hoping as people discover his body of work, he will be offered more roles, and return to Hollywood where he belongs.He's leading man material, whether playing a man's man or a lady's man.Brilliant.

Why would they make a remake on this movie and to change some of it. I liked the beginning and middle but went downhill fast. The actors did a good job. It is hard to jump in the shoes of Joan Fontaine who was great at being mousy. In the book and movie De Winters never ended up in jail. Why change the ending how Mrs. Danvers died? When I saw the beginning and heard "Last Night I dreamed I went to Manderly again" thought this might not be too bad. Sad it changed fast. Watch the original. There is only one Rebecca and it isn't this one.

I saw this film with no expectations - I had heard of the book, but not read it nor seen any other version of it. And I loved this film. It is beautifully shot, and I think the performances gave all the characters some depth and sympathy. The negative reviews seem to split into two camps - its not as good as the book, or not as good as Hitchcocks version. Its always an issue with adaptations/reakes that people come to it with expectations, and then judge against how well ti measured up to those. But Having none, I judged this film purely by what was on the screen, and I would highly recomend it.

Good adaptation if the source material, but I think because I already knew the story from the book that I was less engaged than I might have been.
The film is a typical period piece for most of it but throws in scene more appropriate for a suspense/thriller, which are well done but because the tone doesn't carry throughout the movie they feel out of place.
Overall the movie is fine, but not something I would consider a must see.

This is a movie based on a novel - it is also or I would consider it a remake of Hitchcocks version of the source novel. Now I say that without having read the novel - but having seen the movie that had its 80th Birthday when this was released. Maybe this was meant to honor that Birthday.Whatever the case, if you only watch one of the two movies, I'd tell you to watch the Hitchcock version. While this does a bit of an update (and kind of changes a couple of things ... sort of), the original is better.Having said that, this had a great source and did not destroy that. By having a really good director and a good cast at hand, it manages to do a good movie. And when I say it changes things ... most are shuffled around dialog and scenes. It does seem to keep the spirit and the theme of the original.The tweaks are meant to make certain things better ... which you can question - or you may like the changes. The ending is different - and there is a mirroring on the fate of someone close to Rebecca ... which might make more sense than what the original did with the character ... again, this will depend on your own sentiment. Not many will watch the "same" movie twice anyway.A neat update, but Hitchcock did it better.

Rebecca is one of my favourite books, and, to pre-empt my review, I am somewhat biased in that I've seen the 1940 and 1997 adaptations too. This film is alright, especially for people who haven't seen the others or read the book, but in that case I would recommend just watching Hitchcock's film.The characterisation seems very off to me. Lily James, though excellent, is too well-known to effectively play a timid, schoolgirlish character like Mrs. De Winter, and her age difference with Armie Hammer, who is far too convivial and nice throughout the film, makes the relationship seem perfectly innocuous and healthy. It isn't, and we shouldn't think it is. The dialogue pertaining to Mrs De Winter's youth is almost entirely cut - where once she wished to be "a woman of 36, draped in black satin and a string of pearls", now she essentially...is that woman already. Maxim no longer refers to her as a girl, a child, or a lost thing, and the film suffers for it.Manderley, too, possesses none of what the book or Hitchcock film did. The opening sequence, the exploration of the West Wing, and the final scene do nothing to create a sense of mystery and intrigue - and the number of scenes of servants walking around, giggling, eating, and even singing raucous post-war songs effectively Downtonised the Gothic manor into a placid stately home, which Lily James is unfortunately associated with already.The numerous nightmare sequences throughout the film are laughable, in particular the scene where Mrs De Winter is pulled into the floor by a devil's snare-style vine, and the lingering presence of Rebecca feels pithy; no rhododendrons, no lingering footsteps, and no crashing waves that call her name.Overall, I'd recommend this film, but only as a contrast to the 1940 adaptation, and both of them still pale in comparison to the book. Prepare yourself, though, for Maxim's fiendish mustard suit, worn over four times, and for overt sex scenes that present the estranged couple as perfectly happy before the Big Twist.

reviews.review_title: Sorry to say a waste of 2 hours

A pancake has more depth than Armie Hammer. Avoid this film at all cost.

reviews.review_title: An enjoyable revisitation of a classic novel and film.
reviews.content: When you come after Daphne Du Maurier and Alfred Hitchcock in the classics' arena, you need to be faithful to the canon and yet offer something new. Director Ben Wheatley does a successful job with the former and not so much the latter.An unidentified indigent young woman (Lily James, later to become Mrs. Maxim Manderley) meets eligible Maxim (Armie Hammer) in Monte Carlo and subsequently goes with him to his notable Brit estate, Manderley. The torture she goes through as she finds out the fate of his first wife, Rebecca, pretty much follows the novel and Hitch.Although the principals are attractive enough, they seem to be held back ever so slightly by the film's provenance or direction or both. However, the cinematography is lush and the costumes period friendly, and the film gives plenty of room for the psychodrama Du Maurier and Hitch relished. James is effective as a vulnerable neophyte in society and love, and Hammer projects a privileged glamour while holding heavy memories.Arguably, this story is a feminist work that glosses the domination of men over women. Although the interpretation may not be as applicable now as it was in the 30's, when Maxim controls his second wife, we get it,Rebecca also successfully glosses the meaning of class divide, and more and of marrying out of your class. At any rate, here's a good evening to sit by the fire, sip a cognac, and enjoy your fellow humans making stupid mistakes for love, so relatable.So Brit, so human. On Netflix.

How did did they take a stellar cast, beautiful cinematography, and so much potential and come out with this....? Its one of those films that you so want to be better... but its just not. It was so bland and boring really just full of missed opportunities.
This was a brilliant cast but just failed to engage the viewer...

A romance that embarked on police suspense in the final stretch in an irresistible way, plus an excellent Netflix production... What a beautiful film, I want to see the 40 version, it must be fantastic, adorable...

Such a pity that this huge production with costumes, locations and everything that the 80 years later means have to offer, the result is so much weaker than Hitchcock's film. A great example of how the means do not make art by themselves.

reviews.review_title: A more romantic take on Rebecca but far less interesting.
reviews.content: This 2020 take on the classic novel Rebecca by Daphne du Maurier is more romantic than some of it's predecessors, but lacks the suspense and tension of the Selznick-Hitchcock-Olivier-Fontaine version.I confess, I rewatched my favorite film version of Rebecca right before I saw this film, so comparisons are inevitable. Selznick-Hitchcock's 1940's version is my favorite and lacks nothing for being in black and white. If you haven't seen it, you should.I appreciated the color brought to this modern take and both the French Riviera and the Mandalay home were spectacular in full color.This version built the romance between Maxim de Winter and the "new" Mrs. De Winter, more than in other film adaptation...but in doing so lost some of the obvious tension with their age gap and her being so naïve...and fish-out-of-water-like. Maxim also lacked the wounded and autocratic nature that kind of makes the story work. Also a big criticism would be the personality change that occurs in the "new" Mrs. De Winter when she learns what her husband has done...she suddenly becomes a take charge, take-no-prisoners sorts, which is not in line with her mousy-naïve character.The best acting was probably the role of Mrs. Danvers the obsessed housekeeper, played by Kristin Scott Thomas. All of the other characters seemed like watered down versions of themselves...even the kind Frank.This is the classic story of a young naive girl who meets a dashing wealthy stranger while acting as a paid companion at a resort in the south of france. The two strike up an unlikely friendship and eventually have a quick marriage. Subsequently he takes her back home to England and his palatial home, Mandalay. There she feels very out of place and is intentionally made to feel so by the house keeper who has kept the home as a shrine to the previous Mrs. De Winter, who died tragically the year before. It also doesn't help that her new husband seem reticent to talk to her and has become busy and withdrawn since arriving back home to Mandalay...oh and everyone: guests, staff, townspeople have nothing but wonderful things to say about the lovely, stylish former Mrs. De Winter.But this isn't meant to be a love story and when a body is found...questions arise.My favorite scene visually is the lavish and colorful ball. As a romantic, I appreciated the better romantic story being built between our lovers...but as a fan of good cinema, I missed the suspense and tension.I am sorry to say this was kind of a miss for me, which is a shame because I had been really looking forward to seeing it.

Beautiful scenery, settings and costumes. The story plodded along and the whole thing could've been watchable but for the overacted role of The second Mrs De Winter. This mainly consisted of holding her breath, letting her breath out in fright and jumping and cowering at every little thing. It was excruciating and her characters constant breath holding and fear of everything was irritating and made no sense. I thought that the character deserved a more balanced portrayal.

I normally dislike remakes of successful films. Why do they never remake a stinker?
But I loved this colour remake of Hitchcocks black and white 1940 Adaptation of the Daphne du Maurier novel.
Those moaning about it being less suspenseful are not factoring in the fact that they know the twist.

reviews.review_title: A Beautiful Film That Doesn't Deserve All The Hate, Just Because Hitchcock Did It First.
reviews.content: Rebecca is a magical love story, about a young, maidservant, marrying above her class, to a widowed man, with a troubled past.Inheriting a position which has her living under the ghost of her dead predecessor.In which she not only tries to fill her shoes...but also unravel the mystery behind how she died...and why it left her new husband so traumatized.While being the sort of ride or die woman, every man dreams of falling in love with.Standing by her partner through thick and thin.Going above and beyond to do anything that will keep them together.Overcoming all odds, and everyone set against them.Through the flames of the fire, to purify the past and start anew.While certainly not on par with the original Hitchcock version from 1940, this film is brilliantly shot, and wonderfully acted.Showing that Ben Wheatley cannot be confined to a single genre.Establishing himself as a master of the craft, and outright auteur...by any standards of the metric.A claim to which I'm sure Hitchcock would agree.The locations, cinematography, and wonderfully constructed storyline, certainly make this one of the more high art examples of a Netflix feature film.And though it might not be just as good as the original classic, it's certainly a love story so epic, that it's up their among the top tier of romance films (in my opinion).Do yourself a favour...give this wonderfully constructed, and stunningly beautiful picture a shot.Because it doesn't deserve all the hate, just because Hitchcock did it first.7 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Digital remake offers little new from its 1940 contemporary
reviews.content: What can I say about this film, a remake of a legendary 1940, Alfred Hitchcock film starring Laurence Olivier in turn based on the 1938 novel by Daphne du Maurier.Rebecca is a dead English wife of wealthy widowed Englishman Max de Winter who resides in a Cornish mansion, Manderley.Some time later de Winter remarried a timid ladies companion who in turn struggles to reach the seeming infatuation of everyone to the original Mrs. Rebecca de Winter.The infatuation is at it's zenith with Mrs. Danvers, the loyal housekeeper of Manderley played menacingly in this version by Kristin Scott Thomas.That is the trouble with this film directed by Ben Wheatley, it's basically just a digital colourization of its 1940 contemporary.Each scene seems to be compared to the Hitchcock version seemingly offering little variation from that film.I suppose it offers an alternative to people put off by 'old' movies but I prefer the old!

Maybe a bit more the new one, because all the costumes, and I guess that the character of Maxim is better performed by Arnie Hammer, that is, more real, down to earth. Not to talk Lilly James, she looks gorgeous in this film.
Remember while watching this new one: it's another look to a story of murder. Not romance. Only toxic behaviours and killing

I'm going to try and not compare this to its famous predecessor. To be honest, it's been so long since I visited this story, I'm hoping to be able to keep an open mind with Ben Wheatley's reimagining. With Wheatley's track record you'd think you're in safe hands, but even with the sinister elements to this story, it's an altogether different beast to films like Kill List, Free Fire, High-Rise and the excellent Sightseers. This is what they used to refer to in studio parlance as a 'Prestige Picture'. Big budgets, lavish sets, decadence dripping from the screen. Armie Hammer carries this weight well as the charming Maxim de Winter. He cuts that leading man presence. In fact the cast in general are pretty good, perhaps none more than Lily James, who's destined to become the new Mrs de Winter. You see Armie has recently lost his wife, Rebecca and is spending some time in Monte Carlo (see decadent), where he meets his bride to be as she's accompanying the ghastly Mrs Van Hopper (Ann Doud, of Handmaids Tale fame). He's rich and terribly polite. She's young, far from rich and also terribly polite. If it were to go on like this it'd be shockingly dull. It's not going to though is it. They fall in love, get married and head back to his country pile, Mandalay. And so we swap the sun-swept Med with its burnt orange sunsets and white washed walls for the darker, greener climbs of England. It's like stepping back (further) in time. This is all wallpaper though. As much of a presence that Mandalay is. It's it's inhabitants both alive and dead that bring it to life. The formidable Mrs Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas) is the conduit for all things sinister. The housekeeper at Mandalay, still loyal to the departed Rebecca. She's a little frosty to the new Mrs de Winter, who finds herself living in the shadow of her predecessor, much like this film. Despite Mr de Winter seemingly looking to move on, it's clear he's trapped. The whole house is in a spell. Partly in a sense of duty, but mostly by Danvers. She's the lynchpin character and Scott plays her well, albeit a little obviously. She drives her new mistress bonkers, masking the issues her husband still harbours, as Mrs de Winter (she doesn't get a first name, that's only for Rebecca) finds she's impossible shoes to fill. It's a slick retelling of a maddening story and generally does everything right. It seems lacking heart and and grit though and when you're trying to crank up the psychological tension, that's a problem. Rebecca is an idea of perfection for much of the story and this film seems to be striving for that perfection too. Although it comes up short, that's not to say it's bad. It's a bit long. There's some duff character portrayals, Sam Riley's Jack Favell for one and I'm not quite sure what to make of Sleaford Mods frontman Jason Williamson singing in the kitchen as the toffs party at the ball upstairs. Don't get me wrong, it looks wonderful and the twists still lands with a punch. There's no denying the strength of the story and it grips brilliantly. I just think that modern cinema struggles with tales like this. Too clean, too much knowledge of cinematic tricks, not enough naive experimentation. This was always only ever going to be a rehashing. Wheatley is signed up for more frivolous drudgery, with a Meg and Tomb Raider sequel. I won't watch either, but I imagine they'll be a laugh. He seems all at sea here though.

Had good moments of suspense and mystery throughout the film.

If not, you may wish to skip it.

reviews.review_title: Provides a serviceable update to a classic story for the uninitiated but little more than forgettable thrills for everyone else
reviews.content: "Rebecca" is a romantic thriller based on the novel of the same name by Daphne du Maurier. Starring Lily James, Armie Hammer, and Kristin Scott Thomas, it provides a serviceable update to a classic story for the uninitiated but little more than forgettable thrills for everyone else.After their brief courtship in Monte Carlo, the wealthy Maxim de Winter (Armie Hammer) and his new wife (Lily James) move over to Manderley, the large estate of de Winter's family in England. As she tries to adjust to her new life with the upper class, Mrs. de Winter frequently rubs shoulders with Manderley's stern housekeeper Mrs. Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas), who notifies the former of the untimely death of Mr. de Winter's previous wife Rebecca. Eventually, Mrs. de Winter starts to realise that her husband is not entirely over Rebecca's passing and suspects that her haunting presence still remains at Manderley.There have been various mediums for which Daphne du Maurier's classic 1938 novel have been adapted, ranging from a radio play read by Orson Welles to Alfred Hitchcock's Academy Award winning 1940 feature film. The latter example is probably the most recognised version of this story, as it was helmed by an acclaimed director who became a respected Hollywood figure as a result of its success. Having not read the novel myself, I will be using Hitchcock's film for comparison with this one. With that in mind, this modern 2020 adaptation feels like an inessential and inferior rendition as it sacrifices too many artistic licences for the sake of appealing to today's audiences. Gone is the subtle haunting atmosphere of Hitchcock's film and in its place we have instead surface level imagery obviously intended to provoke the viewer into thinking that something is amiss right away. Sure, this may make the film slightly easier to follow, but it feels like a major part of the original story's identity has been compromised. This lack of imagination may be the sad result of most people today finding it too boring to appreciate the importance of building suspense, which is a huge shame considering the story is littered with moments that revel in such a technique.It feels unfair to compare a director like Ben Wheatley to that of the legendary Alfred Hitchcock but it seems like I have little choice here. Although Wheatley is clearly trying hard to make the film look as nice as possible with creative production design and interesting choices in cinematography, he seldom uses these to his advantage when telling the story. Most of the time it feels as though he is overcompensating for his inability to recapture that feeling of suspense that Hitchcock's film excelled at. Hitchcock was known as "The Master of Suspense" so naturally these are big shoes to fill, but there were barely any moments this time around that actually felt filled with tension. As previously mentioned, this film does away with subtlety in favour of a more sensationalistic approach, which detracts from the gothic atmosphere the original was trying to create. That's not to say Wheatley's direction is terrible, it just distinctly lacks the unique flavour that Hitchcock brought to his film eighty years ago.The cast each did a decent job, with Lily James handling her role as the new Mrs. de Winter to the best of her ability. The chemistry between her and Armie Hammer wasn't always believable, but I did care enough about each of them to enjoy watching their escapades together. Hammer's performance, while fine, did feel somewhat off to me. I suppose it's just that he looks so American to me, and although the fake accent he used sounded okay, he stood out to me more as resembling a chiseled football quarterback rather than a member of the English upper class. On the other hand, Kristin Scott Thomas shines the most as Mrs. Danvers. Thomas plays the character with a more sinister undercurrent than that of Judith Anderson in the 1940 film. This made her role in the story considerably more prominent, as in the original there was a much slower build-up to the reveal of her true intentions whereas here it's plain as day she is plotting something from the very beginning.While I certainly wouldn't call it a bad film, this 2020 version of "Rebecca" doesn't have enough staying power to recommend it over previous iterations. Taken on its own, it's still a perfectly watchable thriller that perhaps modern viewers unfamiliar with the source material may find some enjoyment in, but anyone who has seen Hitchcock's film will leave convinced that no one else will ever succeed in topping it. It is unlikely this will be the last time we see this classic story adapted into a film, so hopefully future filmmakers will have the hindsight to understand what made it so special in the first place.I rate it 6/10

reviews.review_title: What was point of this remake?
reviews.content: This remake was unnecessary. There is no chemistry between the lead characters. Maxim has 0 charisma (unlike when portrayed by Olivier). The scenery (or back drop) is the only aspect of the film I enjoyed.The original film far superior.
Ignore these haters. The movie was amazing, thoroughly enjoyed it. Definitely recommend it!

reviews.review_title: Never read the book and didn't see the original
reviews.content: I liked this. I know a lot of people didn't but since I didn't read the book nor did I see the original film I have nothing to compare this to. Taking this at face value I thought it was well acted and interesting. The only issues I have are this:Armie Hammer - they are still trying to make this guy a thing and despite having movie star good looks he's a dud. And now that some disturbing facts have come out about his personal life it's hard to watch him on screen without thinking he's a cad. He has all the elements and looks good on paper but he just doesn't translate on screen.Kristen Scott Thomas is a good actress or is she? She only plays dour angry characters. Her face rarely changes expression. She's wooden and stone faced. She's got a HUUUUGE nose that is really distracting and so she is hard to look at. Everything about her is severe and now that she's got some years on her all you see is the extreme wrinkling on her face and neck due to all the smoking she's done throughout her lifetime. All I see when she's on screen is the wrinkles so I can't focus on her acting. She truly comes across as someone who would be about as fun as a box of rocks.For me I need to like the actors I watch otherwise I can't get into their performances. For instance I LOVE Oliver Platt - even when he's playing an evil character you still like him and you can also see the acting ability because he truly seems like somebody who is a nice fun decent human being IRL so to see him play against that shows true acting. If someone is just naturally a dour killjoy in real life and then they play that on screen that doesn't really show me acting. Most people like to think that many of the so-called good actors in Hollywood are great but they only see them playing one type of character. Anybody would be good if they just played a heightened version of themselves on screen. It's only when you see an actor play against type in several different roles that you see true acting...examples-Christian Bale, Tom Hardy, Tilda Swinton.I would say the only good thing about this was Lily James. She gave a great performance and made it worthwhile.Lastly this house has been in the family for generations so obviously they have tons of money but the house burns down and they just are relegated to living in hotel rooms? I'm not sure why they wouldn't just start rebuilding the place unless it just held too many bad memories for both of them. The ending almost made it seem like they were penniless now and that just didn't make sense. I felt bad for all the staff who spent their lives in service to this family and now they are out on their ears without work. I know it's fiction but still.

reviews.review_title: A Poor Film with no heart
reviews.content:
So this film is a remake of the famous film directed by the legendary Alfred Hitchcock of the same name and has now made its way to Netflix and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees a young newlywed arrive at her husbands family estate where the legacy of his former wife Rebecca remains.Main Character
Lily James has been in the news lately for some pretty bad things but let's just talk about her performance in this film and unfortunately I didn't care about her character at all. She is just so dull and she never seems like a human being, she is either overacting every scene or just moping about. Also her character is so inconsistent, it is tough to explain without spoilers but she makes some decisions that just feel very strange and like they don't fit with what we have seen throughout the ret of the film.Supporting Characters
Kristen Scott Thomas plays the head maid in the house and I thought she did a good job, she is very chilling and stern in the film, she comes across as a dastardly person and she just does a good job at it here. Sam Riley who I like as an actor has a small role here and I thought he did a good job, it's just a shame that he doesn't have more screen time and more to do here. Armie Hammer plays the husband in this film and he didn't do much for me, he also was a dull character, that I never cared about him or their relationship. They just lacked chemistry and the problem is that neither of them gave me a reason to care about them and this relationship that we are meant to be rooting for.Story
The story in the film has some interesting things in it, especially towards the end of the film as more is revealed about what exactly is going as reveals get made and things get more crazy. But none of it really matters, it is very jumbled and not expanded upon, it is like the film meanders so much for the first half of the film that it has to rush the last act and it is clear to see with a truly awful ending.Script
The script isn't very good, there is no memorable bits of dialogue and nothing that fleshes out these characters. As I said earlier the writing is so poor and rushes lots of its plot to the 3rd act which makes you confused.Style
The best part of this film is that it is really nice to look at, it has great costumes, great locations and great visuals and that is about it. This is a really slow film that feels 3 hours when it is only 2, with not much going on it just feels like a real slog to get through.Overall
Overall, this is a really poor film and shows why sometimes remakes and reboots are just unnecessary unless it is going to be done to a high quality. Save yourself 2 hours and skip this one.Rating - 3/10.

A struggle to keep from switching Rebecca off. Very long winded and uncompelling. Lily James just about held the film together largely because of her beauty and her costumes. But the film lacked substance and felt lightweight. The actors interpreted their lines but forgot to engage emotion. They came across as unlikeable and unbelievable. Armie Hammer was wooden, charmless and not a bit mysterious and Kristin Scott Thomas played her usual icey role which we have all seen her do many many times. If the pace had been faster and they edited out a good half hour, it might have earned an extra star.

reviews.review_title: Some Patience is Required but Rebecca's Central Mystery Justifies a Watch
reviews.content: I might have been able to guess that Rebecca is a remake/re-imagining of an older movie, it has all the telltale signs. From the more contemplative pacing (more on that later) to the lovingly shot cinematography, it just has that kind of feel. But on that note, Rebecca looks great. The environments are beautiful and lavishly captured, it not only makes you want to visit but it invites you into the future Mrs. De Winter's perspective. How could she not fall in love with this lifestyle and grab onto the first kind rich person who pays her attention? I want to extend some credit to Ben Wheatley and his team (specifically DOP Laurie Rose) for not only making everything period accurate but bringing some visual flair to the production.The movie is angled around a small and select group of actors so this section will be short. Lily James is always a welcome presence, she's a favourite of mine. She's not only great but she makes interesting choices and despite this being a remake, this is another intriguing performance. She elicits a lot of sympathy for Mrs. De Winter, she tries to be kind in the face of the cruelty the world throws at her, she tries to support her distant husband and make the best of a flawed situation. This is another good performance and I'll continue to try and catch stuff she's in. Separating Armie Hammer's work from his personal life (yikes), he puts in the time in Rebecca and while I had a small disconnect with his character, he exudes strength and patience as Maxim de Winter. Kristin Scott Thomas does an excellent job as the duplicitous and ultimately villainous Mrs. Danvers. Her reasons are clear and she did a good job of making Danvers initially sympathetic and it made her turn that much more demoralizing.I don't often watch movies in this genre, gothic period pieces are full of melodrama and the problems of the wealthy. It can be tough to care about and initially the pace of Rebecca compounds the problem. Unless you're immediately attached to Maxim and his future bride, the movie meanders around when it comes to their courtship and lacks direction back at the estate. Also, I may be reading this differently with my modern lens but Maxim's lack of desire to help Mrs. DeWinter acclimate is puzzling. She's struggling and having problems with people bullying her, maybe he could have helped with that? This could be a bias of mine though so take it with a grain of salt. But when the wheels of the plots finally start to turn, I was interested in where things were going and the conclusion punctuated the buildup pretty well. So if you're willing to give Rebecca some time to shift gears, it will deliver the required payload.A lot of the critics were questioning Wheatley's intentions of remaking Hitchcock's classic. I'm normally not a fan of Wheatley but coming into this with fresh eyes (I never saw Hitchcock's version or read the book), he got the job done. There are some good performances, pleasing cinematography and an interesting central mystery. If you're looking for something with some action or that moves at a quick clip, Rebecca won't be for you. But if you want some heavy drama wrapped in a mystery, check this out on Netflix.

A useless exercise in style over substance. It's hard to believe the script writers had even read the book it's based on. Go watch the Hitchcock version instead to see the film by someone who can actually direct a movie.

reviews.review_title: More of a soap opera but still decent enough
reviews.content:
It is targeted at a modern audience who can encounter this actually quite terrific story. In its way its more glamourous than the Hitchcock film and build up more as a soap opera rather than a romantic thriller. This is where the film mainly lacks and no I don't compare it to the "Original" but that interpretation just worked better for me. This is however not a bad film either. The first half was actually quite great and built up the story wonderfully, but the second half fell rather flat. Everything was rushed and the development of the characters remained "on the road". Acting wise it was decent. Armie Hammer was well chosen for this kind of role and played it fine. Lily James had the looks but I am still not too sure of her talent especially in such complex roles as the one of Lady De Winter. She did her best, but it was not a performance to write home about.
The best performance came from Kristin Scott Thomas. You can blame her for being a bit overthetop and her character being a bit too cartoonish but she held herself well against that and a bit of both is also needed for that role. The look was great, sometimes just too perfect and too clean. Nice costumes and great art direction. A fine score by Clint Mansell. Its an okay film but not something that the world needs. At least it was decent entertaining with some atmospheric moments

What a dud. Hammer has the acting chops of a box of Wheaties. Collins seems lost in a part that's clearly too big for her. Only the always top-notch Kristin Scott Thomas redeems this limp disappointment. Oh, Keeley Hawes and Sam Riley are also excellent in smaller roles. The script and direction are simultaneously choppy, inattentive, and uninspired. Quite bad, really.

Yeah, to be honest this film was incredibly underwhelming for me and I'll tell you why.The film, as stated in the title, lacked any sort of spark. At no point in the film do you get hooked in by the plot and eagerly sit awaiting the next part.There is no need for it to be that long. The film felt very long winded and the middle hour of the film could genuinely be condensed into about 4 minutes.the film is classed as a thriller and I have no idea how. More like a romance period piece. The "twist" is very underwhelming and you are led to believe that there's a ghost/spirit roaming about and the film is heading in that direction. It doesn't in the slightest, which renders so many conversations and plots null.-the final 20 minutes of the film is so out the blue, I really don't see the point of the vast majority of the film.Couple of positives to take is that the acting I thought was very good. And the character arc of the main character was pretty good also. But that's kind of it. 4/10 from me, not worth the 2 hours to be honest.

As with Netflix's remake of THE BOYS IN THE BAND I'm wondering: why? The revision doesn't add much that's new - a glamorous cast, lovely locations and colour in place of black-and-white. The story is meant to be "timeless", but aren't there any new stories out there waiting to be filmed?Mrs Danvers is the key character. In the 1940 version her obsession with Rebecca was threatening and creepy - it was even possible to read in a lesbian undertone. Kristin Scott Thomas is heroically starchy and becomes subtly sinister, but this year's script makes her more patronizing than obsessive, and the battle between her and the new wife is more a power struggle rather than a study in psychosis.Lily James gives us a feisty Mrs de Winter, but Armie Hammer's transition from attentive boyfriend to absentee husband is unconvincing (his English accent suggests he was voice-coached by Prince William). The melodramatic climax lifts the plot out of a rut but, far from satisfying, it is almost ludicrous. Times have changed, and maybe REBECCA is a bit too dated, and a bit silly, for today's audience. Dated and silly doesn't usually spoil an Agatha Christie remake (looking forward to Kenneth Branagh's new DEATH ON THE NILE) but it doesn't work for this Daphne du Maurier adaptation.
