Rebecca
2020
12A
Director: Ben Wheatley
Starring: Lily James, Armie Hammer, Kristin Scott Thomas, Keeley Hawes, Bryony Miller, Tom Goodman Hill, Sam Riley etcOverall rating 81/100Rebecca is based on two newly weds called Mrs De winter (Lily James) and Maxim ( Armie Hammer) who upon arriving to his family estate learns about his past with his dead wife as secrets unravel. I really enjoyed Rebecca and I thought It was a cleverly crafted and entertaining movie so lets get started.First of all, the cinematography, set pieces, chemistry between characters and performances were fantastic. This movie looked visually stunning, the fantastically crafted shots with the atmospheric use of lighting and fog was just excellent, the set pieces were also beautiful, wherever this was set I want to go, the manor was absolutely breath-taking and was also a great place for multiple different parts of the manor and for the mystery to unfold. I thought the characters were very likeable and had excellent chemistry with each other. The character played by Lily James was so incredibly likeable you instantly sympathised with her situation before meeting Maxim and just had a fun and unique charm to her Lily James and Armie Hammer did fantastic performances here and had fantastic on screen chemistry with each other, there relationship felt very organic and real and they worked very well together, the performance from Kristin Scott Thomas was also excellent, she was incredibly unsettling and switched from sweet and smiley to menacing and cold so excellently she was a fantastic antagonist.My next few positives would be the mysterious and unsettling tone and the development of the mystery. I loved the mystery this movie created, the fact that they left so much out about Rebecca and her relationship with Armie Hammers character was excellent, I was genuinely intrigued and on the edge of my seat throughout, the movie also created a very unsettling tone, the constant comparison between Lily jame's character and Rebeca and the fact that the residents of the manor almost acted like she was still there was terrifying and gave the movie a supernatural feel to it that worked really well, I also loved how the mystery developed, I loved that they slowly revealed more and more things about Rebeca and the movie constantly left you questioning characters and leaving hints which was great and there was always enough new reveals to keep you constantly interested.My few negatives for the movie that bought it down slightly would be the unneeded characters, rushed character decisions and lack of depth to the more interesting themes. I felt like there was a few characters that didn't really contribute much towards the plot the lady who Lily james's was travelling with didn't contribute anything towards the plot and just felt very unnecessary to her character, I also found that the rushed character decisions between Maxim and Mrs de winter effected the pacing, the fact that their relationship moved so fast and too fast for a normal relationship it made the first act feel very rushed and more messy compared to the rest of the movie which didn't have these issues. I also found the movie lacked depth to it's more interesting themes and played it safe in places, the more interesting class themes were not explored and due to the class differences between both main characters I wish this was more well explored.My final few positives would be the clever links between the characters, plot twists and final act. I loved the links that the movie made between Lily james and her character as well as Rebecca, the constant comparison with her character almost unintentionally doing actions similar to Rebecca was excellently executed and the conflict that caused was pieced together perfectly within the film, the plot twists were also excellent, I never saw any of them coming and was genuinely surprised at the direction the movie went, but it raised the stakes and drama well and further cemented the movies cleverness and attention to detail with it's mystery leading to a shocking and entertaining final act that left an impact.Overall, despite playing it slightly safe with it's themes and a few character issues, Rebecca is a visually stunning, excellently acted and phenomenally crafted movie that has a mystery that will keep you constantly on edge and entertained.

It's always exciting to see a remake of a story without knowing the original. "Rebecca" is based on the novel of the same name by Daphne Du Maurier, which was implemented very successfully in 1940 by Grand Master Alfred Hitchcock. The remake of the material was released under the direction of Ben Wheatley and celebrated its premiere in 2020 on "netflix". It should be clear to everyone that a Wheatley is not a Hitchcock. Still, I was very disappointed with the end result.A young woman in Monte Carlo falls in love with the handsome widower Maxim de Winter. He wants to marry her pretty quickly and takes her to his estate in Manderley on the English coast. But Maxim's late ex-wife still seems to play a major role there. He doesn't want to talk about it, but the staff keep talking about her: Rebecca. The young Mrs. De Winter quickly realizes that she is not welcome here...I can't give much praise, but at least the two main actors do their job properly, even if they rarely have the chance to show what theyÃÂ´re capable of. The landscape shots are also good and very impressive here and there. But what is missing is a good script and charm."Rebecca" from 2020 is such a typical, lengthy wannabe thriller that rarely creates real tension and also fails in the romantic part. Unfortunately, Hammer and James have little chemistry. The only romantic moments are coming from the pretty places they travel to. The characters all talk to each other in fake "film language" and often explaining things only to the viewer, not Lily James' character. And it is she who should know about the late ex-wife. But neither her husband nor anyone else gives her clear information. I get it: They want to make it seem mysterious and exciting, but itÃÂ´s just frustrating to watch. It requieres a very talented director to do something like that. Or a good script.
So it's no wonder that she keeps getting into a series of embarrissing situations so that the forced drama can take its course. But that is not a natural structure!In addition, there are cheap scares that are supposed to justify the thriller genre, but none of it was creepy or exciting. Especially not if you don't care about the characters or you can't understand their actions (for example, how can Lily James endure Armie Hammer for so long, if he closes himself off to her?).Clint Mansell's music didn't really convince me either. Nicely composed, but used far too inflationary.Conclusion: "Rebecca" is a boring and uninspired wannabe thriller that I don't like even without having seen the original. If anything, it sparked my interest in the Hitchcock film, but unfortunately I can't get much more positive out of it.

I love the setting for this movie and was perfectly happy to settle into its rather theatrical start. I have no regrets watching it but was rather confused about the potrayal of some of the characters. Ann Dowd plays the excellent aged dowager Mrs Van Hopper whose long life appeared to have fueled her with a roaring furnace of nasty innuedos. I liked the characterisation of Mrs Van Hopper has being a stereo typical witch who despises youth, admire social status and is rather scathing of love. But Mrs Van Hooper's aged witch in this traditional romance should have been offset with an innocent snow white. Lily James with her brassy locks, fabulous wardrobe and come hither looks is no Snow White. Lily James has not even the tiniest amount of sympathy for her horrible but sick employer and is quick to lie to get her on way which would be ok but her decision to spend oodles of time being a wealthy man's play thing seems rather ill advised. However, the shedding of a few tears pays off and Lily Jame's wins her prince being the insipid but tall Armie Hammer. The prince whisks Lily James away to a beautiful mansion where she sits alone with insecure and obsessive thoughts which in turn fuel quite a bit of snooping into her husband's late wife's life. The snooping of course drives her a tiny bit potty. The ordianry kind of new romance potty rather than Hitchcock lock me up potty and hence it appears the story tends to reward her obsessive need for her husbands approval. Likewise her husband killing his ex wife in fit of passion is also considered to be a good thing. In my opinion the true heroine of this movie driven by love to maddness, is Kristin Scott Thomas who plays Mrs Danver's. My heart broke over her unconditional love of Rebecca and her overlooking all of Rebecca's flaws because she sees her adored Rebecca as a women who flouts tradition and needs no prince to rescue her. I adored Mrs Danver's cool icy stares and feel that her story of women in service too old to marry and too old to find another position (no rescuing prince in her life) is a far more interesting tale. Her bitter end was an ode to the only out of many women in her position. Mrs Danver's and Mrs Van Hopper both offer many cynical words to Lily James and many of those words to represent the state of many marriages of that era and the fate of many women. However, in the genre of romance Lily James does not seem to heed the messages from the shadow sides of the older, much lived women and instead seeks only to see the optimistic light of romance offered by her wife killing but insipid prince. Once Lily James has killed off, in her mind, any competition she can settle into being her true good wife self. Hence the final scene depcits a sexy Lily James, smoking with a hot husband in an exotic location searching for a marvellous forever home...which left me mourning all the more for the cold and watery fate of Mrs Davers
Taken on it's own merits .This is a well acted film and beautifully made .Nothing can beat the original of course .However, if you haven't seen that .There would be no reason ,not to enjoy this .

Is a good thing dogs exist in these movies. How else would our characters find things they shouldn't? I like Lilly James, I like Armie Hammer, and I like Ben Wheatley but I didn't like this. After an explosive opening act stuffed with as much romance as possible, it grinds to a halt.After that opening act, which could be a full movie on its own, it turns into vague mystery drama. Girl gets married to guy who refuses to talk about his past wife who somehow everyone loved. It's the type of movie that gets old after the first vague story told by one of the house workers. That is the entirety of the film unfortunately.Scene after scene we watch Lilly James overacting in various rooms while listening to people jabber. It's painfully tedious. Even with the gorgeous locations and nice cinematography it can't maintain any energy. Any time there's a new "reveal" it feels as unimportant as the last. Which there aren't many of in the first place.This just doesn't give any reason to get into the story. The Rebecca character that is constantly talked about isn't compelling to me. Everyone loved her, ok, so what? Not only that, but Lilly James is horribly uninteresting. She has no character or arch. She is a tool to be used in the story. Don't write like this. And if your story is a string of scenes where people talk at the main character, change it.

Daphne Du Maurier is one of my favourite authors and the Alfred Hitchcock adaption of Rebecca is rated in my top films of all time. So hearing that there was a new adaption to the screen of Rebecca left me with a feeling of both excitement and dread. However, I was determined to watch this adaption without prejudice. I would blank my mind of previous adaptions for screen and go into with an open mind and heart and that is exactly what I did.I think sometimes when a fan is so loyal to a book or film they become completely closed off immediately to a new film adaption and refuse to give it a shot. I can say this, because I have done this before.I am glad, I let this adaption of Rebecca have a chance with me, because I can say that I enjoyed it.No, it did not have the great build up of suspense that Hitchcock's version had. How could it? That was Hitchcock and no one can compare to him.Yet, this was beautifully shot, the acting was lovely and I think it did the story justice.Lily James as Mrs. De Winter was stunning.I think if you can give this a fair go and not be stubborn about it, you might actually enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: Vapid and unfortunately -given the material and the cast- disappointing
reviews.content: Du Maurier would laugh in the face of whatever poor soul decided Rebecca needed a Hollywood makeover.This is a story of faulty people committing a long series of mistakes (and crimes) and yet instead of us the audience being filled with dread, we are made to react with apathy to whatever ill befalls them. I'd even go as far as to say that the most sympathetic figure was, in fact, the one that was created to be the embodiment of a scary, haughty, gothic character: Mrs Danvers. Which really makes me question the creative decisions made here that allowed me to get to such a conclusion.One thing that makes Rebecca (the novel, and the character) so tantalizing is that it's always right on the verge of the supernatural. We're given plenty of hints to let our imaginations run wild, but are never told about any actual explicit ghostly happenings.This film reduces the atmosphere of the book and the mystery surrounding Rebecca by simply portraying her as a promiscuous woman who finds out she has terminal cancer and instead of suffering to the bitter end she commits suicide by cop with the "help" of her enraged husband.Said husband hides his crime, evades the law and is allowed to roam free, even though he is, in fact, a murderer.Wrap this up with a make-shift happy ending that was never meant to be, given the story, and what are we, as an audience, left with? Certainly not the deliciously disturbing story Du Maurier gifted us with.

reviews.review_title: AS MRS DANVERS SAYS: YOU CAN NEVER REPLACE REBECCA - THIS PROVES IT!
reviews.content: If you like a light, stylish period romantic drama then you might enjoy watching this but you'll be very unlikely to remember it. That's why this is so different from "the real" version. Had the 1940 version never been made then this might be viewed more favourably but as hard as I tried to watch this without comparing it, it's impossible not to. As a stand-alone film, it's actually ok. It looks good, it's filmed beautifully and wastes no time pulling you in to the chic and stylish world of the oyster eating, champagne quaffing set holidaying on the Côte d'Azur of the 1930s. Essentially this is an episode of Poirot - the one where he's investigating a murder at Downton Abbey.Compared with the Hitchcock/Selznick version, this feels like one of those high quality TV adaptations of something or other which you watch but also know that it will be made again in a few years' time with whoever is that years' big star. There's nothing wrong with this, it's just nothing special whereas the original version was. The acting is good, but it clearly is just that, acting; it doesn't feel real. As impressive as she is, nobody's going to remember Kirstin Scott Thomas' Mrs Danvers. She's sinister but because Judith Anderson was somehow inexplicably scary without seemingly having to put any effort into it, her Mrs Danvers epitomised the word sinister. In my mind, Lilly James is probably the sweetest girl in the whole world and it should be a criminal offence to say anything bad about her - however she just isn't 'The second Mrs de Winter.' Joan Fontaine was wonderfully timid and pathetic - she could play that part because it was 1940 when to an extent, woman 'knew their place'. If Lilly James tried to be as wet it would just seem weird but that's what this role called for - so not Lilly James' fault! As for the guy playing Maxim, again his characterisation suffers from two things - it's not 1940 and playing someone with 1940s attitudes again would seem forced and two, he's not Lawrence Olivier. Olivier's character was cold, aloof and gave the impression of hiding something very, very nasty behind his frosty façade. This new guy just doesn't convey any mystery or danger, he's just too nice.

reviews.review_title: Horrific, and not in a good way
reviews.content: A total waste of time. The original Hitchcock film and the novel are far better. Some shots in here look nice, but that is it. Ann Dowd's brief performance is the only competent one in here. The main cast is shockingly poor. James and Hammer have no chemistry, and James doesn't have the talent to even make an attempt at what has made this character so compelling over the years. Particularly disappointing is Kristin Scott Thomas; if she can act, you wouldn't know if from this film. Mrs. Danvers is stiff and cartoonish in here hands, and that is perhaps this film's greatest sin.Skip this and watch the original.

I did see Hitchcock's version but that was decades ago and too long to remember the detail. I'm reviewing on the basis of it being a new version that is stand alone. Based on that, I was thoroughly entertained and can honestly say what a good leading lady Lily James is as the second Mrs de Winter, the first being The Rebecca of the title. We never learn the first name of Lily's character that I noticed. Armie Hammer is Max de Winter who marries Lily and takes her back to his mansion 'Manderley". Ben Wheatley's direction is glossy and more modern than Hitchcock's, as you might expect, but it is expertly done. Perhaps more of a gothic, darker feel may have garnered higher marks on here, nevertheless I liked it. I notice most lower rankings are from diehard book or Hitchcock fans of the originals. I was really impressed by Lily James, not for the first time, although on the negative side I did find a slight lack of chemistry between her and Armie Hammer but felt that was more down to him than her. Kristen Scott Thomas is suitably sly as the troubled Mrs Danvers, the house keeper who harbours an obsession with the dead Rebecca. A subtle lesbian fixation relevant to the times. Sam Riley is also good as the rakish past lover of Rabecca who returns to cause mayhem. No really weak performances from any of the large cast members in fact that I could see.I'm giving 8 stars out if 10, primarily for Lily James' central performance as she acts at first bewildered, then excited, then intimidated, then frightened, then determined and finally triumphant, a real spread of acting talent from one of the UK's more magnetic leading ladies of our times.

People who have given low rating are just either , they have no knowledge about the novel or they haven't watched the 1940 version.Usually a movie of a renowed film maker like Hitchcock should be greater than the other ones.I watched both versions as well as read the book to understand his style in filmmaking. I decided to compare all of them to see what is Hitchcock's style actually is.I expected that I'd dislike the 2020 version but I kind liked it more than 1940 version. The new one is visually pleasing and interesting and doesn't feel bland like the old one.The production and costume design itself is great than the old version. The new version stays true to the source material they have covered almost 90%.
But hitchcock picked an awesome book and turned it into a hitchcockian film.Believe me this version is better.

I was brought up on the "original" Rebecca with Olivier and Joan Fontaine. This is quite a sensitive and imaginative version for the 2020s. Lily James might be a little too beautiful to play the second Mrs de Winter but she manages the gaucheness and inexperience with aplomb. The male players are all competent and well cast but the real star is Kristin Scott Thomas as Mrs Danvers, who conveys perfectly a mixture of obsession, love, grief and total lunacy. Most enjoyable, particularly as the proper Mediterranean locations are used in the early sections. Lovely period detail, especially the cars. Jack Favell's 1939 Lagonda can park on my driveway any time!

reviews.review_title: A beautiful remake/adaptation that you don't have to see the original to enjoy!
reviews.content: Seen the original, didn't care for it. Maybe I just wasn't in the mood. Need to see it again. Am loving this one though!!Visually stunning, well-cast, and great tone. I am really finding this a joy to watch on a lazy afternoon. The perfect relax in the shade with a glass of iced-tea film. Romantic, stylish, mysterious. All the classiness of the past, with the sleekness of today.I am watching this because I have been on an Enya (musician) kick the past few days, and she lives in an actual castle in Ireland, which she named "Manderly Castle" after the Manderly in this story. She is a big Hitchcock fan though, so I'm sure that is the version of "Rebecca" she loves. That said, I feel she'd enjoy this one too- just like I am! I'm only half-way through so far, but so far, it's perfect!On another note, Lily James is quickly becoming one of my most favorite actresses, between this, "Mamma Mia: Here We Go Again!", "The Pursuit of Love", "Cinderella", "Pam & Tommy", and "Yesterday" I can always count on her to be in projects that interest me- like beautiful period pieces such as this one! And she's adorable here too.
A movie that offers nothing new, but can be enjoyed without problems.

Although I don't think they nailed the screenplay for this story, it was still a rather fun fueled mysterious entertaining ride. I don't think Armie Hammer and lily James have much chemistry... I like them separately but don't work too well together. Which is pretty integral for a romantic movie.If you've seen Hitchcock's version or read the book I would imagine you would hate this adaptation, luckily I haven't seen either.Not the greatest movie, but I'd say it was worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Anodyne and no malevolence. A dumbing down of a wonderful book.
reviews.content: This began quite nicely with good sets and then very quickly went downhill. The language and manners were not in keeping with the period and it felt like a vehicle for Lily James rather than a proper film. Kristin Scott Thomas did her best but sadly the actors and acting were not memorable and the screenplay was dire.

I was unaware of the fact that this was based on a novel and had been produced once before by Hitchcock, starring Laurence Olivier. Had I known I might have skipped this and watched that version instead. This was indeed a disappointing plot. I found myself expecting some devilish twist, turning the obvious upside down, but no, this plot is just as predictable and expected as you think it is as it is played out. I quite enjoyed the performance of the two female characters but other than that, it was quite a poorly and sloppy production.

The acting wasn't up to the caliber you usually get from these actors, but I guess that could be blamed more on the poor writing and directing. This updated version lost the nuance, cleverness, and suspense of the original 1940's Hitchcock film. The director revealed too much too soon (with the character's demeanors and personalities not being more subtle) and he didn't invest enough time in the details of the plot, so the audience doesn't get to experience the full mystery this movie should be. With much of the tension removed, this film was a bit slow and drab, even frustrating, nothing close to the Hitchcock film, IMHO! 12/2020

reviews.review_title: If you have something better to do, do it
reviews.content: Really disappointing, the clothes, KST and AH are beautiful and those are the best bits. Falls short of the Hitchcock classic, it's neither dark or a thriller.

reviews.review_title: I love the book- the film not so much
reviews.content: Casting for me was way off for all the characters. A gorgeous man (John Hamm) would have been great, Mrs. Danvers (Chloris Leachman) Rebecca should have been featured in memories at least and the main character should have been more mousy. The house wasn't as spectacular, no rose garden, no flora and fauna...the scenes of the french coast were beautiful. Such great material in the story itself - wish they had stayed more true. If it tells you anything I started vacuuming the last 10 minutes. Rather boring...didnt care.

For the record, did not read the original story, did not see earlier film versions of it and with that I can only say that by the end of the movie I was waiting for a plot twist of some sort, some real suspense and it was like the dinner guest that never shows up. I don't see where the story is all that good to begin with when compared to say, an Agatha Christie story turned into a movie. I am mystified how #1 this got made at what cost and #2 that anyone would find it enjoyable or satisfying once they had sat through two hours of it waiting for that certain something that never materializes. great locations , cinemaphotography, good acting and a story that is just not that interesting or even suspenseful. Two hours 'out to sea' along with Rebecca.

"Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again". As one of the best-known openings to a novel, it deserves to be treated in a film adaptation with all the weight it carries for the reader of the book, imbued with all its evocative Gothic spine-tingling foreboding. And yet, what we get from Lily James's narration is a deadpan, matter-of-fact voiceover that may as well not even be there but for its iconic status. It adds absolutely nothing to the film. This sets the tone for the entire movie: a crisp, loud, overproduced Hollywood slickness at odds with the tale of grimy undercurrents of stiff-upper-lip depravity encountered by an ingenue hopelessly out of her depth in a marriage and a household conspiring, ironically, to keep _her_ the spectre she has always been.
For glitzy production values, this film scores highly. The sets and camera work are lurid, the costumes (barring a ridiculous tweed sports jacket worn with mustard linen pants, repeatedly) in themselves beautiful, the upstairs-downstairs tropes trotted out faithfully; winsome actors behave winsomely (or diabolically, as the case may be).
But, for all the things it could possibly be in 2020, Du Maurier's 'Rebecca' is none of that. Like its eponymous character, it is haunting, spellbinding, unrelenting and perverse. The key source of pathos - and the genius of the novel - is not in the protagonist's clawing at the air or hitching up her skirts and running to her room to weep, but in the sinister, the unsayable, the unsaid. Ben Wheatley, rather, makes a point of saying everything. Loudly. Perhaps such an unsubtle re-telling was calculated to appeal to a lazy contemporary audience, and, if so, it probably succeeds and deserves more than 3 stars.
However, there are so many ways in which Du Maurier's novel can be re-read in the first half of this century that could still indulge well-worn and familiar tropes without dumbing down the screenplay or hamming the acting, or simply trashing historical or textual accuracy (Mrs de Winter's trashy suicide blonde hair, Mrs Danvers wearing makeup). The feminist and queer subtext of the novel, the dynamics of social class, the moral ambiguity of many of the characters, all deserve more than a garish cardboard cut-out treatment in today's cinema that is not hampered by the restrictions that were faced, and so deftly circumvented, by the Hitchcock (there, I said it) version.One cannot, and should not, expect a film adaptation to precisely reproduce a novel. But to turn it into a pop-up book does grave injustice. Even entirely on its own merits, the film does not hold together well. While Ms James tries hard to love the camera, one does not get a sense of her sheer terror, nor her motivation for it - it is all circumstantially dictated by her surroundings, not her performance. Her transformation into a determined chatelaine-detective hell-bent on protecting a husband for whom she had little affinity until he "opened up and showed his emotions" will no doubt resonate with some viewers, but, independently of its inexplicable departure from the novel, stretches credulity. As charming as Ms James is as an actress, the role requires more nuance and depth than charm: she does neither dowdy and skittish nor grimly empathic very well. Her success in portraying "gaslit" would be more at place in a remake of the famous Bergman melodrama than in a Gothic horror. She looks pretty, but the second Mrs de Winter is not a pretty character.
Armie Hammer as Maxim is unfairly given a character whose lack of cohesiveness renders him almost an afterthought worthy of a romantic lead rather than a man whose demons multiply and torment the immature psyche of his inconsequential second wife. After their initial meeting, belonging more properly to a romantic comedy, there is no chemistry between him and his spouse, not even negative chemistry, purely because there is no substance to him.
Certainly, there are highlights. Kristin Scott-Thomas in particular as Danvers does a commendable job of transcending the flamboyance of the script and direction to create the sense of menace engendered by a character whose derangement and passion have been heavily suppressed.
Overall, if you have not read the novel, or were unmoved by it, then you may well thoroughly enjoy this film for its lushness and the transparency of its narrative. You may find the melodrama compelling and the facility of its "messages" easily digestible, but I wanted more of less and less of more.

reviews.review_title: Well done. Good re-make of a cinematic milestone
reviews.content: Kristen Scott Thomas has the chops to do soooo much more. This film suffered from the limitations of the film makers, but it was pretty well done. Rebecca is a cinematic archetype, and trying to remake it is a tall order; whoever made the call to 'make that film' has balls and a possible ego issue. The original can't be improved. Period. But this re-telling was enjoyable enough.... I just couldn't get the thought that KST is too big for it, too good, too 'Danvers' compared to the rest of the cast who are pretty enough, but not quite as talented; and the crew who are good enough, but not good enough to exploit KST's full potential.

...I have to agree with another reviewer: I wish the proverbial THEY would just stop with the blond hair on this one. If they want Imogen Poots, then GET Imogen Poots, ffs. (I love both of them, ftr.)Got some Hunderby vibes, where any one of the cast would burst out laughing at any given time. Too bad they didn't, I was getting very angry with everyone. I was first generation Feminism (not to be confused by today's frothing at the mouth type: Getting angry at a character instead of everyone else seems...healthier); so I was upset that the New Mrs. DeWinter didn't put everyone in their places. Esp Danvers, "Good grief, you're the most expendable person in the place now that your direct employer is a corpse, ya stupid bloody cow..." I mean, really.But I stuck with it, as I am a fan of nearly everyone in it. Glad I did, still had Hunderby and Jane Eyre vibes: I am much better with happy endings. Far too many crappy ones in real life.If you absolutely adore beautiful things, places, clothing, etc., than definitely give it a go. If you are sensitive to a pack of adults bullying another adult, it will get you aggravated for a while. Give my beautiful things, homes, decor, furniture, scenery, fine living ANY day. Not sure why that's a crime these days, but too bad for those folks.

A boring movie made by a mediocre director.
"But "Rebecca," directed by Ben Wheatley from a screenplay by Jane Goldman, Joe Shrapnel and Anna Waterhouse, is a flimsy cardboard box full of nothing. " The New York Times

I've read Rebecca 3 times and watched many versions of the film. Some stay close to the book and others don't. This is my favorite adaptation. The writers took some liberties with the story, but in this case it worked brilliantly. The chemistry between Armie Hammer and Lily James is infectious. This adaptation is a must see.

reviews.review_title: If you want to see Rebecca watch the original
reviews.content: Sad remake. If you are going to rip-off the story, rip it off. But no, they stole the outline of the story and rewrote the details in ways that undermine the whole story.If the writers wanted to tell another story do the work and write another story. Instead, they hijacked Hitchcock and drove it into a ditch.This review isn't a spoiler but the movie is.

This movie is not bad, but it's not great either. Lily James is always a pleasure, and her acting was fine, but her character was not very likeable. Even her evolution from insecure and pathetic to confident and decisive is undermined by her willingness to make questionable choices. Not one of the characters was really likeable. Overall the film just feels bland.

reviews.review_title: Great acting, but 20 mins too long...
reviews.content: Lily James once again proves that she is 1 of the best young talents we have acting out there today. Armie Hammer also turns in a fine performance, but also aggravates at times. The story is slow and the cinematography is BEAUTIFUL. Overall it was fine... just go into it knowing it moves slowly. It felt like 3 different movies in one. Worth the watch for the acting alone though.

reviews.review_title: Give it a chance. Do not listen to the bad rating bandwagon.
reviews.content:
Judge the film based on performances instead of the actress' private life.
The acting is much better than most thriller/ murder mystery films. Armie's performance was never dull. Overall, I like the chemistry between actors. It's not the best film I've seen but NOT that bad, it kept me entertained for awhile.Improvements to be had: I just wish they cut some scenes short, ie, Mrs Denver's and Mrs De Winter, and focus more on the ending and the punchline.I felt like they went round and round on circles, yes, we get that the second wife and the house manager will never be best friends, just get on with it.

The materials used in the movie, such as, the house, everything in the house, the clothes/dresses, the environment were really really good. The cast is very good also even though the story is not including all details in the book. It deserves overall at least 8/10!

Disappointing interpretation of an iconic book. Casting is all wrong. I was open-minded and hopeful when hearing about the newest film version.
The movie didn't inspire questions/mystery and left nothing to the imagination or interpretation- which is the key point of the book. Instead of having empathy for the new Mrs. de Winter and what she experienced on a daily basis, I found myself annoyed by her insecurities. Though cinematically beautiful, it was disjointed and lacking. The talented Armie Hammer wasn't a fit for the mysterious mister de Winter. The same with Lily James. Just read the book or rather enjoy the audio version performed by the talented Juliet Stevenson..

His attempt on doing a British accent was basically the worst I've seen in Hollywood for some time. It was like he wasn't even trying, it seems like he forgot to put some effort on it.Even thought it has some great actors on the production, it was very disappointing and too superficial.

Not near as good as the book or the 1940s version. I love Lily James but honestly didn't like her in this role. The plot was rushed and if you aren't familiar with the story you might get confused and bored.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyed the story more than the film itself.
reviews.content: I knew nothing about this film but it was a suggestion on Netflix and the trailer seemed good. What convinced me was it being a recommendation from Jan Eyre, which I love. It was good enough that I'd happily watch it again but not quite good enough that I'd recommend it. It was missing that emotional ride that has your heart pumping out of anxiety or romance. What I did really enjoy was the actual story, and having now found out about Hitchcock's version I'll be looking to watch it and hopefully enjoy this story even more.

reviews.review_title: Kept me on edge the whole time
reviews.content: Honestly I thought this movie was going to be just about revenge and heartbreak. I was proven wrong and loved every moment of it! The cast is exquisit and their performances kept me second guessing what I thought the next part or revelation would be. Amazing cinematography too! This movie is the suspense thriller I was hoping for and much more!

Totally horrible movie, sinfully boring like a hallmark channel movie
What a snooze fest
Only plus thing is performances from actors, it was just fine, but story is so horrible that nothing can help it.
It was boring from the very start and they dragged it too long , story plot was weak ,wasted my time.

The actors are good but the story is dull. Keep promising interesting story lines, interesting characters, but in the end these interesting elements lead to nothing, and you don't even understand why they were in the film at all...

The film Rebecca (2020) is unforgettable due to being weak and poorly conducted when compared with the Rebecca made in 1940, having Laurence Olivier and Joan Fontaine in the main roles. The performances in the 2020 version are also pretty weak. Armie Hammer (Maxim) has a bad performance in his role as the widower of the unforgettable Rebecca, Lily James has an average performance, changing her behavior in unexpected ways throughout the story. Kristin Scott Thomas is so loaded with makeup that she cannot express in a visible way any emotion. To top it off, I don't really understand why Maxim is so fond of that rather scary yellow suit he wears in several scenes in the film. It was one of the worst movies I've seen recently.

So disappointed. I was looking forward to the film after loving the book. However, it seems they simply took the key plot points from the book, muddled them up, slung them together, did their best to get through the story as fast as possible and said "that'll do".
Very poor movie. 3 stars given purely for the casting and performance of Mrs Danvers.

reviews.review_title: Didn't quite live up to the story
reviews.content:
I first watched the 1997 version and loved it so much that I read the book and then watched Hitchcock's version and loved that version equally as much. I've read the book many times again after and read its prequel 'Rebecca's Tale' too.Needless to say that I was equally as excited as I was apprehensive at this version. But I felt disappointed by the end at the whole movie.The cinematography is very beautiful but the story just isn't quite there.Although not every film version of a book has to stay true to the story this film version could've greatly benefited from not deviating so much and making such unnecessary changes.I love Armie Hammer as an actor but I would've preferred an English actor to portray Maxim de Winter.Lily James also did not feel right in her role. Even if her physical appearance fits the role her acting was irritating and unnatural at times. I didn't feel like she was right as Mrs. de Winter and I do feel like she's a little too overrated as an actress. I'm sick of seeing her in films just for the sake of it.
I personally would've preferred to see Carey Mulligan in the role.On another note I actually think that Kristin Scott Thomas was a splendid choice. It's just a shame that she played Mrs. Danvers in a not so great version.

Despite the beautiful settings and the lovely choice of actors, the story became more incredulous as it progressed, deteriorating into an amateurish mess that the actors had to then try and make the best of what was a really poor final ending.

Is there any movie made by Netflix that Lilly James is not in? I personally like her, but it's amazing how many times she has shown up in movies that I have watched at Netflix this month. Sometimes she's a blonde, sometimes she's a brunette. She's both in this movie. I never saw any of the previous versions of "Rebecca", so I can't compare, but the story as told in this film is pretty dull.I guess since I knew Hitchcock made a version, I was expecting more suspense, if not terror. There's really no suspense in this version, unless you are easily alarmed. (Don't watch it if you are sleepy.) Plus, it was hard to feel much of anything for any of the characters, except for maybe the young servant being falsely accused of stealing. He was wiping a tear away from his eye.

I was bouncing between pleased and horrified when I found out about a new version of Rebecca. After all, the story is a classic and how bad could it be?
I knew that, imo, Max was portrayed as far too young and Lily James is far too pretty to play Mrs de Winter no.2., but Kristin Scott-Thomas as Mrs Danvers spurred me on and I wasn't disappointed, consummate professional that she is. However, my 2 stars are for her and the sumptuousness of the locations. And that's it.
The story is supposed to be full of suspense that has you wondering what's going on. How will the new Mrs de W cope, thrust into the life of the elite when she hasn't got a clue? Let alone being made to feel inadequate by the ghost of the first Mrs de W still pervading every corner of Manderley and the heartbreaking realisation that your husband still grieves for her. She can't hope to escape Rebecca's presence and this hangs over everything like a pall, even affecting you new marriage.
The whirlwind romance was supposed to lead you into the real meat of the story, but then it was badly rushed. Was everybody as fed up as we were and wanted to go home?? Where was the build up? Mrs Danvers nearly succeeding in driving Mrs de W to suicide was over in 2 seconds and the final, amazing revelation that stuns the wife as well as the audience was thrown away!
Oh please, in the future at least get a director who has read and understands the book. I'm afraid Hitchcock, even with the 'Hollywood' ending, is still the king....

reviews.review_title: The fact that everyone is only highlighting the inconsistency of the costume is blowing my mind
reviews.content: This movie is not great but it is not bad, and i enjoyed it. reviews.review_title: I'm not a devoted Hitchcock fan, I was really looking forward to this, but ...
reviews.content: I am not a devoted Hitchcock fan, and while I enjoyed his version, I never found Laurence Olivier a convincing lover. Charles Dance did a much better job in the '90s miniseries of Rebecca. I have seen Armie Hammer and Lily James in other films and enjoyed watching them. So, I anticipated this version eagerly, and expected to enjoy it, especially as I had read it was not a remake of the Hitchcock version, but had gone back to the novel. I do not think the problem with this version is the acting, it's the script. I had read the novel many years ago, and re-read it recently, which is perhaps why I found this version so jarring. Max De Winter was a strong and ethical character (apart from that incident with his first wife LOL). Yet here he is portrayed as a wimp, submitting to blackmail, and sitting around with his head in his hands while his second wife is off saving him. This did not happen in the book, or the Hitchcock film or miniseries. Max refused to be blackmailed and was instrumental in finding evidence to get himself off the hook. The second Mr de Winter was a cringingly timid character, completely lacking in self-confidence. Yet here she is driving Max's expensive car, marching into the servant's hall, sacking Mrs Danvers, organising a ball and ultimately saving the day. None of which happened in the book, or the Hitchcock movie, or the miniseries. This complete change in the characters and the plot is what spoils it for me. It is also completely incongruent. This story is set in the 1930's, most confident women didn't behave with the independence that the second Mrs de Winter did in this film. This tinkering with the past, trying to re-write history is very annoying. Another example is with Max's great aunt Caroline de Winter, in this film it was stated that she was one of the earliest women doctors of her time. Another complete fabrication. Yes, we should have strong female character in film and TV, but set them in a realistic time, or make it a fantasy (eg Wonder Woman). The only redeeming feature of this film was Kristin Scott Thomas who did a wonderful job as Mrs Danvers. I'm left wondering why the changes in the story. Did Netflix think they could improve on the story written by Daphne du Maurier? Did the political correctness department intervene? As the lead actor, did Lily James demand a better role, to be the hero? Whatever the reason, for those involved to say they went back to the source material, ie the novel, is astonishing.
Every movie with her inside already deserves a 6 from the beginning! :-) Then if the movie is interesting some points can be added... but this wasn't the case.

reviews.review_title: None of the subtlety or richness of the original
reviews.content: Huge budget, and they still manage to dramatically fail at 'good cinema'; this film is a perfect example. All the beautiful aesthetics in the world couldn't save a bad script, obvious dialogue and terrible direction. The 4 is simply for the fact that I didn't want to tear my eyes out, thanks to the casting and scenery.Skip this, and please opt for the shouldn't-have-been-touched-by-Netflix classic!

reviews.content: If you're familiar with the book, you'll find yourself becoming frustrated extremely quickly. For example, only the very first scene of the first ten minutes happens as it does in the book.This had real potential to be a good film but, sadly, it's not.
The suspense, the mystery and the acting, PERFECT! I wouldn't read the negative reviews if you wont see it for yourself. It was definitely worth my time.

I've never read the book or seen any previous version, but I enjoyed this. The leads had chemistry and the villain(s) really angered me which is what is supposed to happen. The settings were gorgeous.

reviews.content:
Act of all casts is too weak and lily james is very awfull in her roll
movie has nothing and it was boring
i give 2 star just for dressing.

I generally like some of the actors involved, so was expecting so much more with great source material. The changes added nothing. Really bad acting and no subtlety at all. Characters development non existent. Lacks soul.
I was so looking forward to this movie. It was a terrible disappointment. Good cast just misdirected.

I watched this without knowing anything about Rebecca or even that it was a book, and I quite enjoyed it. It is generally well acted and has good suspense. Then reading the reviews here where so many people bash this for "having no reason to exist" given that there is a 1940 version from Hitchcock which is apparently perfect, I went ahead and watched that one for comparison. I must go against the grain here and say that the Hitchcock version is significantly worse (gasp!).For instance, the performance of the actor who plays Maxim in the 2020 version was nothing to write home about, but 1940's Maxim is so badly acted it's almost comical (in contrast to many good actors in that film such as the new Mrs. de Winter, Ms. Danvers and Favell). Furthermore, the music simply does not match the scenes at all (happy, cookie-cutter, bland music permeates the entire movie, playing even during suspenseful scenes, creating a massive mismatch between the moods conveyed by you're seeing and what you're hearing). The new version did a much better job of handling psychological tension and suspense.In short, I really have no clue why so many people are bashing this remake and saying that the 1940 is better, other than "OMG IT'S HITCHCOCK SO IT'S OBVIOUSLY A MASTERPIECE, AND IF YOU DISAGREE YOU ARE AN UNCULTURED LOUT". Sigh.

Why bother when you have nothing to add to the original, and even do not manage to hit 10% of the thrill it creates? I am afraif to say but I found the remake extremely pointless and a waste of time. How did they manage to make the scenario & the flow of sentiment in the movie so incoherent? As if we are watching a collage from carious genres?! So disappointing.

I hadn't heard of the book or the original movie and watched this because Netflix recommended it to me. It was okay. The beginning was really good and suspenseful but then it just fizzled off and became quite boring during what should have been a huge ending.
It was watchable.
I didn't read the book and I didn't see the older version of the movie either, but this one was great! I loved it!

I was very interested in reading the book, it's been on my list for a long time. Then came the Netflix movie and I decided to watch it. Now, I no longer have the slightest desire to read the book. Incredible poor and dull plot.

Its lacks the dialogs and suspension.

reviews.review_title: Exquisitely beautiful with heart of darkness just as Du Maurier defined Rebecca
reviews.content:
The non human characters in this film elevates it above the ordinary. Mandelay is
Exquisitely beautiful with heart of darkness just as Du Maurier defined Rebecca. Gothic but not horrific.
How beautiful was the bedroom in the west wing. Clever to have Rebecca leave her boudoir via a mini corridor in mirrors. There are so many small gems to spy in this sumptuous gem of a film. Such as Mrs Danvers' toy playing with a bird artificially trapped in a cage. Maxims name in Mrs De winters' sun tanned back The sprites and sea nymphs that burst from the Cornish waves beckoning, luring Mrs Danvers. The fire in Maxims eyes. From the narrow Cornish streets and fish market to the astounding Monte Carlo in summer sun. A cinematographic excellence.
Higher still in the accomplishment league comes the actors' performances : The grotesque Mrs Van Hopper, Jane Lapotaires dementia of granny and the desperation of those around her. Armie Hammers delightful happiness as he falls in love with the next Mrs De winter. Counterpoint to the rage in his expression at Favell. Deftly avoiding melodrama. Lily James' character was a triumph of modern adaptation. The contradiction of Joan Fontains' version (which was wonderful in its day) of a timid little innocent becoming the rock that Maxim depended on. Turned into a strength from the start albeit unworldly, evolving into the tour de force, defying the onlooker to interfere in her final over his shoulder glare. Wonderful! But the highlight of the performance has to be when she is released from the torment by Maxims confession that he hated Rebecca. The pain leaving her face is palpable. Trying to find out who is the second Mrs De Winter by first name it becomes clear that Du Maurier never intended for there to be the possibility of comparison. Rebecca was a centre of self obsession, Mrs De Winter the second was wife and soulmate to Maxim.
If difficult to follow Olivier and Fontain, imagine being compared to Judith Andersons Danvers! But Kristen Scott Thomas made it her own. A deliciously modern interpretation that explained the twisted descent into hopelessness and grief. Rather than the psychopathic. Much less posturing and blank staring. Allowing the character to smile and be helpful echoes modern smiling vipers !! Not exactly preferable since the original is undeniably great........just different and a cinematic joy. After all who needs repetition ?!!

reviews.review_title: If you want to read the book, read the book
reviews.content: Such a shame a good movie like this is getting bashed by people who read the book and are hoping the movie lives up to their imagination. I did not read the book and thought the movie was a breath of fresh air from the mindless Super Hero, Zombie, and Dystopian movies that are constantly coming out. Yes, it was a remake of 1940 movie, and is based on a book... Could it have been better? That's not for me to decide.But as someone who knew nothing about this book/plotline, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. reviews.review_title: 30's costume drama at its best, stunning scenery
reviews.content: It became clear very soon that this movie was a mix of 50's cinema style storytelling and typical top notch English costume drama. Both are exquisite, both cars, houses, roads, persons and their costumes and customs, outside and inside of stunning buildings, completely genuine to that era in Europe and England. It is somewhat of a classic fairy-tale Cinderella story with the evil stepmother (Mrs. Danvers) included, carefully woven into a typical love-crime-drama that we used to see in American cinema. All of the players are at their best and in this slow paced, predictable, somewhat stereotype movie.A definite must-see for fans of the genre and people interested in that era, but probably a lot less interesting for the average Hollywood-type movie viewer.

First of all, the aesthetics of this movie were absolutely gorgeous which allowed the movie to remain, in the very least, visually intriguing and engaging. I have to admit that I've never read the book or watched the older version of the movie, but I enjoyed Lily James' and Armie Hammer's character performances. They weren't outstanding, but they were convincing and entertaining and visually appealing as a couple. You could really feel for Lily James' character throughout the story which added a needed emotional aspect that was quite effective. The movie did a good job of making you feel as though you were personally witnessing the events of the plot, giving it the feel of an intimate peek inside the secret lives of the characters. One of my only complaints about the movie is that I feel like they could have built up some of the more important scenes. A few of the turning points in the plot could have been made a bit more cathartic in order to make it more of a drama. I still found these turning points satisfying, but I feel as though they could have been presented more dramatically. I also wasn't a huge fan of the ending. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't particularly powerful either. I'm not sure how fans of the source material feel about the movie, but I found it thoroughly enjoyable. Even if you are a huge stickler for the source material, it is a worthwhile watch at least for the splendid visuals, cinematography, and entertaining performances. I am likely to rewatch this film on a rainy day.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, but the ending is seriously unfortunate
reviews.content: It's of course impossible not to compare this to the 1940 Hitchcock classic, and let's just say it: it's not as good. But it's better in some ways. I actually liked Hammer's approach to Maxim better than Olivier's; Olivier was so overbearing that I had to wonder what the heck the nameless Joan Fontaine character saw in him, other than his money. Hammer walked the line between loving and domineering pretty well. And Fontaine's totally meek and submissive approach was probably about right for 1940 viewers but it's always hit me as creepy; Lily James did much better for a modern audience. Kristin Scott Thomas is a terrific actor, but sorry, nobody but Dame Judith is ever going to be Danvers. She owns that role.Couple of things, though. First off, the tacked-on ending was really bad, reminding me uncomfortably of the idiotic framing device in the original "Invasion of the Body Snatchers." What the heck were they thinking? WHY did it need a happy ending? That was a bad, bad choice. A smaller but weird thing is the use, in two different places in the movie, of Pentangle's recording of "Let No Man Steal Your Thyme." Pentangle was a unique English folk/jazz fusion group whose sound absolutely reeks of the late 70's, and the song is about men who abandon women, which has nothing to do with the plot of "Rebecca." It's generally just bizarre and inappropriate, and I say that despite being a diehard Pentangle fan. Also, it's been a while since I read the book and I don't remember exactly how Danvers meets her end there, but the iconic scene of her staring out the window as the house collapses on her in the Hitchcock version is so powerful that any other ending seems anti-climactic.All in all, not bad, I'm glad I saw it, but it's not a patch on the Hitchcock version. (And any fans of the Hitchcock version really need to see the Mitchell and Webb sketch about it: just look up "mitchell and webb rebecca" on YouTube. It's one of the most brilliant pieces of sketch comedy ever.)

Thomas in the role of Mrs. Danvers.With all due respect to fans of black-and-white movies and older cinema, these two titles are simply incomparable. James interprets the role of a lower-social girl whose charm could not be resisted by the wealthy Mr. De Winter (similar to 'Cinderella' in which we also had the chance to see her).After a brief romance, he takes her to his lavish estate as a wife, where a romantic fairy tale slowly loses its intensity and moves into drama/mystery...The aforementioned Rebecca is actually the late Mrs. De Winter whose 'ghost' is still present in the house. Let me start by daying I am a huge fan of the book and although I always enjoyed Hitchcock's 1940 film version, I always wanted to see a modern remake and was so excited for this one. (I have also seen the 1970s and 1997 TV versions which were fair, but not remarkable).Well. Having seen this pile of drek, I now have a fresh appreciation for Hitchcock's film, no doubt the best we'll ever see since no one else can seem to get it right. For starters , the CASTING. UGH!!Armie hammer - as bland as wonder bread and downright comical in a mustard colored suit. Wrong age, wrong looks. No mysterious appeal.Lily James- overrated actress. She comes across too poised and confident in all her scenes, where she is supposed to be playing a shy, awkward, insecure young woman. Evidently shyness isn't feminist-friendly so they toughened her up and gave her a chic, stylish wardrobe for "empowerment". But this just kills the whole point of the story and the character itself.Kristin scott thomas - there is only one actress who could have slayed this part: TILDA SWINTON. I've been saying this for years. Total missed opportunity by the casting crew. If you read the book and saw her in The Chronicles of Narnia, you will know exactly whtat I mean.The rest of the cast is, in a word, forgettable and not even worth the honorable mention.Casting grievances now off my chest, I can sum up by saying pretty much EVERYTHING is wrong with this movie. Characterizations,
pacing, plot, dialogue, costumes, everything. I can find no redeeming quality. It feels slow and tedious in parts, then overly romantic (no tension or suspense whatsoever), then rushed and clumsy in the final act. They threw in completely unnecessary changes like Maxim sleepwalking (I kid you not), Mrs. Danvers having a tender bonding moment with Mrs. DeWinter, Mrs. Dewinter being the one to discover Rebecca's medical records and save the day (again, to make the feminists happy), and Mrs Danvers throwing herself off a cliff. None of these things served to improve upon the book in any way.Cannot un-recommend this movie enough!!! Zero stars!

I thought the actors chosen were perfect for the roles, and I liked this a lot more than the pbs adaptation, although that one wasn't bad either. I'd recommend it 100% to anyone who read and enjoyed the book. For others, I'd recommend if you're into gothic brit lit. It's not an action flick, so don't expect to be on the edge of your seat. reviews.review_title: Poor reworking of a classic story.
reviews.content: I was so looking forward to this adaptation, but in the end it was a struggle to see it through to the end. There have been three adaptations of this wonderful novel. - 1940 Hitchcock. 1979 Jeremy Brett. 1997 Charles Dance. All three of these are good adaptations of du Maurier's novel, each with their own merrits.Alarm bells stated to ring when this latest adaptation of Rebecca began to be marketed as a 'reworking' for a newer audience. As such they altered, added, changed, and removed key parts of the original story to a shadow of it's original self. There is a reason why stories become classics and this classic did not need 'reworking'. This could have been so good with the quality of actors and writers involved but instead, by tailoring for 'the next generation' who should know and learn the original instead of having things 'adapted' for them, they killed a classic story and squandered those talents involved.

Hard to compete with the Best Picture Winner of 1941 and the 2020 version isn't anywhere close.

reviews.review_title: Do not go into this thinking it's a remake of the 1940 movie
reviews.content: I've been reading reviews and the single biggest reason people don't like it is because they are comparing this to the 1940 classic movie by Hitchcock. This is simply another book adaptation. With a couple of major differences, this sticks to the book very well. It's not without problems, but I must say, the few great aspects of this film are so good that they enhance the whole experience and make this deserving of a higher rating.Starting with the negatives so I can gush over Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas for the remainder; I must say the movie had serious pacing and editing issues. Some scenes were too short, cut abruptly to the next and seemed misplaced. It's like they shot 100 scenes, and just cut and pasted them one after the other. My other issue with this movie was the soundtrack. Hearing modern songs just takes you out of the movie. And the suspense music that plays loudly whenever you're supposed to be on the edge of your seat does the exact opposite. I truly believe the movie would have benefited from less music. Let the silence add to the unsettling nature of this story.Then we have the issue of tone. The famous Daphne Du Maurier book navigates the transitions between romance, thriller and mystery perfectly. There's an air of darkness everywhere, and it's mainly because you're in the mind of the main character when she's being harsh on herself and anxious about everything. That anxiety is translated onto the screen by one means: Lily James. That's it. The movie doesn't do anything to help her. The color are bright, the costumes are beautiful, the soundtrack is sexy... I wanted more torture, more anxiety. The only time I got that was when Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas were together on the screen. More on that when I write about what I loved about it.The last issue I had with this was Armie Hammer. It's not about his age, yes he's not 42 like the book - but it's him in general. He's basically eye candy, and I couldn't help wonder what it would have been like if someone with actual acting abilities had played Maxim. He didn't exactly play the quiet, depressed, powerful man. He was just a bland, rich, handsome dude. He didn't command respect and he wasn't mysterious. I can't really think of anyone who would have done this role justice, at least not anyone who's around Armie's age. I keep thinking of Alexander Skarsgård, but he's older. Also, what was that accent? He just sounded like someone who was trying to sound old Hollywood.Now, off to the good bits. The good bits are so good that I kind of want to re-watch this movie multiple times just to witness them again.Lily James was the single best thing about this movie. She's proven she's a talented performer multiple times now, but this is a difficult character to play. In the book, you understand her because you're literally reading her thoughts. To translate that into a performance is a daunting task which I believe she absolutely nailed. The nervous, shy quality of her character in the beginning of the film came across as authentic. To credit the writers, this was also because of scenes like her dropping the money when trying to bribe the staff or walking in front of a group picture being taken, etc.Then gradually, this character grows and matures. It's so subtle that you can't really decide when exactly it happened. But when it's half way through the movie and you go back to the start, it's so apparent. This is the single best development I've seen in recent years. There is no "I have to come into my own and be a woman warrior" moment. It just happens organically, and that's in a large part thanks to Lily James. She play someone insecure, unsure, and vulnerable who matures into the person that fights for what she wants brilliantly.Then, the best thing about the movie: When Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas appeared on screen together. Their scenes were intense, unsettling and charged. Lily's body language, the actual terror and discomfort in her manner and Kristin's powerful presence and haunting gaze was just the best thing. I would watch a whole 2 hour movie with these two just staring at each other! The scene where the second Mrs De Winter finds Rebecca's room and Mrs Danvers shows her around is the best scene of the entire movie. The colors are just right (the icy blue tone of the room, Lily wearing a blue/green shirt, Mrs Danvers in navy blue) gives you the sense of coldness, the acting is top tier and the dialogue is brutal. To think that they have these actors to work with, and can actually create scenes like this that have you hold your breath throughout and didn't utilize that is disappointing.So to sum this up, I enjoyed this film for what it was. A Netflix movie. It's clear they didn't want to make an Oscar-winning film. (They really could have, though) This is a romantic mystery, not thriller. The editing is problematic, and Armie Hammer does nothing but to be tall and handsome. However, the movie has a secret weapon in Lily James, and a winning combination of her and Kristin Scott Thomas. I'd say the whole thing is worth the watch just for these two. My 8 rating is simply because these two were beyond excellent.

Overall this was a decent adaptation of the book "Rebecca". I will start with the positives. In small ways it actually was more true to the book than Hitchcock's famous adaptation 1940 film of the same name. The cinematography was fantastic, and the shots were stunning. A lot of gorgeous views.
The acting was okay. It going to be difficult if you have seen the original and are expecting Laurence Olivier and Joan Fontaine. While Armie Hammer and Lily James are fine, they don't match up. The stand out is easily Kristin Scott Thomas. She steals the whole film, which isn't surprising - it's Kristin Scott Thomas!
This version actually sticks to Maxim shooting Rebecca, as he does in the book, rather than her falling and hitting her head. So, points for that. Though, they added extra scenes like Mrs. Danvers throwing herself into the water to commit suicide rather than dying in the fire. It wasn't needed.
The reason this isn't getting higher stars from me has got to be the very end. We see a changed Lady de Winter smoking cigarettes with an ominous crashing of waves as we cut to black. Neither the book or Hitchcock's version took this dark turn. It takes away from what the character had to overcome in the film. It changes the whole story - and in a bad way. Had they left that entire scene on the cutting room floor, this would have been a better movie.

reviews.review_title: Quite removed from the source material but looks pretty
reviews.content:
Good points:-wonderful cinematic shots and use of colour, the symmetry and lighting truly made for a visually appealing watch
costume design appeared to be true to the era (at least from my impressions)Bad Points:
The second Mrs. de Winter was written to be so shy that she would mend her own undergarments in secret to relieve her from any judgment from her maid, Lily James' version has her looking directly into Mrs. Danvers' eyes and being so bold in front of the staffex. In the novel and in the Hitchcock version (1940), she admits to breaking the cupid statue only in front of her husband and with embarrassment, but in this version she rather confidently, although tearfully, admits to it in front of the staff too, which she is supposed to be intimidated fromMax de Winter is not old enough, he doesn't have the allure of mystery and a tortured soul like Laurence Olivier and most importantly Jeremy Brett had, Armie Hammer comes across as just a rich kidThere was no, I mean non existent, none at all, nuance to Mrs. Danvers sapphic love for Rebecca. It would have been better if the audience was given the chance to pick up on her dialogue and possessiveness of Rebecca to get to that conclusionDanvers was creepy which was great, but a bit too much that it seemed unbelievable that Max did not act up or see how uncomfortable his bride was, almost made Danvers a mother-in-lawthe soundtrack was overwhelmingthere was use of CGI that looked absolutely terrible. Ex. while in the cabin during the confession scene, the second Mrs. de Winter's face is reflected in a dirty mirror but its so obvious that the mirror is artificialLast points, personal ones:-There's a scene in the novel where after Max confesses to the murder and asks his bride " Will you look into my eyes and tell me that you love me now?" and he kisses her with such passion and all she thinks of is the curtain behind his head, and she's completely calm although she has wanted nothing but for Max to love her all this time. This is the part that changes her, Max is truly hers and she is no longer insecure. I wish that this scene would be shown, no adaptation has done so.-Caroline de Winter's dress was changed from the large white one that had puffy sleeves and a large floppy hat like the novel and Hitchcock film had to a red velvet one with gold jewelry. I don't understand why it was changed, it's unnecessary and just annoyed me.

I am not sure why people feel the need to dump on this so harshly. It had a few problems: the overuse of computer graphics, for one. However, if can you enjoy it without spending every minute comparing it to the Hitchcock version, it is a simple escape. Even though it went against the book, I enjoyed the fact that they were closer in age, and the chemistry that brought with it. Her employer can then raise a question about trapping him with sex that continued to resonate for me, as a source of the character's doubts about her marriage. Hammer's performance also brought out something I hadn't perceived before, which is Maxim as a (psychologically) abusive husband. Until the big reveal, he is becoming a man she'd do well to leave. It was interesting to see her take a more proactive role in saving him. For those who wonder about her willingness to stay with a man who killed his wife, Du Maurier clearly intended Rebecca as an evil, abusive character who knew how to provoke him into a crime of passion. Finally, I liked that the ending allowed them to have some happiness together. I have never understood why in the novel after the events of the story, they are living what seems like a colorless, almost unhappy life together. They have lost Manderley (though he still has the land and wealth, presumably), but Manderley was a burden to both of them in different ways. He was not imprisoned for what anyway would be termed a crime of passion. They love each other. Of course, it's not a truly gothic novel if they are happy in the end. And perhaps it was the convention of the time, that because the crime went undiscovered (but not unpunished, re: the actions of Mrs. Danvers), they can't be truly happy. Anyway, this version allows them to be free and together...even though it leaves a chill when the ending implies that she now has a bit of Rebecca's ruthlessness.

Wheatley's Rebecca is solely a dramatisation, and does no justice to the original novel. It is full of spectacle and air where the plot should be. 

Rebecca, at its core is a psychological thriller exploring the deeply sinister motives of a murderer (Maxim De Winter/Armie Hammer). The strange, one could almost say reverse Oedipal complex which dominates the De Winter's isolating relationship is the focus for the entire narrative - his patronising and arrogant comments ‘I'm asking you to marry me you little fool', and infantilisation of his new wife, ‘You've lost that strange  young lost look I loved' suggests pedophilia, and yet in Wheatley's interpretation of this classic horror, he has sadly conformed to the trivial and painstakingly untruthful idea - that Rebecca is solely a Gothic romance.

 The cinematography and golden age glamour perhaps distracts from the obvious lack of characterisation from Lily James, whose charming buoyancy is the opposite of the shy, timid and easily persuaded young Mrs De Winter. Aside from the incredible characterisation of Mrs Danvers, (Kristin Scott Thomas), the narrative indulges in the romance of a man twice the girl's age (which is, again, omitted) with soft sex scenes on the beach and unnecessary ‘romantic' smooches. The use of the red dress to symbolise promiscuity for the ghost of Rebecca is sadly obvious and superficial, whilst the lack of key symbols, such as the rhododendrons (female sexuality) are omitted. Sadly, it can be concluded that Wheatley has falllen, or rather indulged in the popular theory that Rebecca is a romance, and attempts to please his audience through glam and glitter. 

If you want to watch a visually beautiful film and have not read Rebecca, you will be delighted if slightly disturbed by the visual hints at the unequal and dangerous power dynamic between the couple. If you know Rebecca, you will be outraged at the like-ability of this narcissistic murder, and confused by the dramatisation.
An OK remake of an OK original.
Must admit watched the first 25 mins only,  so disappointed, screenplay just bland and had no feeling.

If you have seen the original version of Rebecca that was done in the 1940's, you might appreciate this movie more. Rebecca is Daphne du Maurier's crowning achievement as a novelist. It is a romantic mystery with a touch of noir and the paranormal. The story is peculiar because it leaves you perpetually distressed, yet hopeful for a happy ending. It can translate well to the big screen. I like the older movie better, but this is still good and I would never discourage anyone from watching it. I gave it 4 1/2 stars. Given a choice I would watch the old version over this one because that's what I grew up with.
the book was annoying but better

This film missed the mark. I can never understand why filmmakers decide to make a film based on a book if they know they are going to completely change the principal characters and vital plot points. It's an insult to the classic Rebeca by Daphne Du Maurier for this film to have the same name as the book. I have to wonder if the screenwriters' and director even fully read the book or if they decided to take the concept and loosely make a movie based upon it; the movie is inspired by, not based on the book; so much of the story and the people has been stripped away, it's something different entirely. Here's a tip: if you're writing a screenplay based on a book but can't even keep the essence of the main characters, simple details, the theme, or important plot points, and have to add in scenes that would never occur- then maybe don't write or make the film.

In no meaningful ways surpassing its predecessor, this version of Rebecca shines only in that it is visual stunning, and well acted. The plot beats are stilted at times, and the narrative lacks focus. I wanted this to be great, instead I was passably entertained. I love Lily James, and she embodied her character perfectly, I found it hard to get behind many of the characters decisions. That pulled me away from the narrative as it was centered on her.

I started watching with the expectation that this remake would never touch the 1940 Hitchcock classic. For the first two thirds of the movie I must admit I found it rather entertaining, hewing close to the 1940 film.  But in the final third the film went off the rails.  I never read the book, so I checked Wikipedia to see which film more closely resembled the Du Maurier novel.  It turns out that this movie is much closer to the original source material.  However, that doesn't mean it is a better movie.  The same thing happened with Mildred Pierce. The 2011 miniseries with Kate Winslett was  closer to the novel, but Joan Crawford's 1945 film was much better.  Anyway, this Rebecca really isn't really all that bad, I just think it's more worthwhile to invest two hours in the earlier film.

Lousy direction, lousy editing, lousy story telling... and the WORST costumes I've ever seen on a leading man and leading lady - ill-fitting and unflattering.  

The wealthy Mr de Winter has one pair of un-tailored, baggy, *tan* pants to wear the entire time he's in Monte Carlo.  What's that about?   Even his pajama bottoms aren't cut right. Everything the character would have worn would have been tailored to perfection for him.  If they were bought off the rack they would have looked better. 

Speaking of pants, the second Mrs de Winter's baggy white slacks look horrible on her, evidently cut from the same pattern as Mr de Winter's pants. 

A wonderful, talented cast is wasted in this choppy, flat, mess of a movie.
I enjoyed this immensely.

There is not much originality in "Rebecca". It felt like a hybrid between "Jane Eyre" and "Crimson Peak", but with the disappointment that Maxim de Winter murdered his first wife in the end. There's an old saying in the movie business cautioning against remaking the classics. That's especially true when a director attempts to follow in the footsteps of a legendary director. It's advice that would have been well heeded with regard to this remake of the 1940 Alfred Hitchcock classic "Rebecca." When a naive lady's traveling companion is swept off her feet by a wealthy English aristocrat in Monte Carlo, she's soon overwhelmed by her new life when she joins him back at home as his new wife, becoming the lady of the house at his sprawling seaside estate, a mansion where the ghost of his deceased first wife allegedly still lives on -- and with whom he is apparently still obsessed. While the film features a superb BAFTA-nominated production design, gorgeous cinematography, and excellent performances by Lily James, Kristen Scott Thomas and Ann Dowd, the suspense factor that made this picture's predecessor a classic is virtually nonexistent here. Instead, this offering tediously rumbles along, tossing out occasional mildly interesting revelations but never reaching out and grabbing viewers in the way that a Hitchcockian-type tale should. The story even becomes somewhat at muddled as it moves toward its conclusion, diluting the impact of whatever modest chills it may have built up along the way. Indeed, this release is, once again, further proof that, when it comes to emulating cinematic icons, it's generally best to leave well enough alone.
